abstract: Chief executives widely praise Pres Bush's speech, saying it would help restore confidence in American business; but many Wall Streeters and those who run large pension funds that own billions of dollars in stocks express disappointment Bush did not offer more specific proposals to clean up corporate wrongdoing; two points of view represent competing visions of current scandal over corporate behavior: executives who feel their credibility is at stake and investors angered by cascading series of financial losses and string of accounting failures; institutional investors feel more sweeping changes in boardroom rules and accounting oversight are needed, while others, mainly business leaders, say they oppose any move toward greater regulation; Felix Rohatyn, longtime Wall Street financier, says he was hoping for more commitment to regulatory reform and to corporate governance reform; United Technologies Corp chief executive George David says speech was needed because people are losing confidence; Bethlehem Steel Corp chief executive Robert S Miller says Bush struck nice bipartisan balance; Sealed Air Corp chief executive William Hickey suggests jail time for executives who rob shareholders; Thermo Electron Corp chief executive Richard F Syron says companies should put as much emphasis on traits like integrity and honesty as they do on technical skills when selecting executives; Albertson's chief executive Larry Johnston praises Bush's speech; California Public Employees' Retirement System chief executive James E Burton says his concern is whether speech was just more political rhetoric or whether it was truly call for action; Council of Institutional Investors executive director Sarah Teslik expresses disappointment; Corporate Library executive Robert A G Monks says nonsense of not calling stock option an expense should be stopped; Peter G Peterson, chairman of Blackstone Group, calls speech 'too little, too late and too general'; Goldman Sachs chief executive Henry M Paulson Jr says Bush is serious about driving abuses out of system; lead_paragraph: Online Travel Agent Books Directly With the Airlines
abstract: Online Travel Agent Books Directly With the Airlines  Following through on one of its most provocative business plans, Orbitz, the airline-owned online travel agent, will begin booking tickets directly in the reservation system of American Airlines. The setup allows Orbitz to bypass the reservation systems that handle nearly all of the airline bookings by other travel agencies.    Another eight airlines have agreed to create similar links with Orbitz, and the company says the fee that it will charge airlines will be about one-third what they are paying most other reservation systems. lead_paragraph: Tracing a Common Name
abstract: Tracing a Common Name    Q. Since the million daffodils given to New York by the Dutch in remembrance of Sept. 11, I find myself at odds with a neighbor from the South who calls them jonquils. Isn't a jonquil something else?    A. Daffodils, nature's apology for winter, belong to the genus Narcissus. All daffodils can be called narcissus, and vice versa. But jonquils are a special case. Colonists brought Narcissus jonquilla and similar species and selections when they came. These daffodils took a liking to the Southeast because, as natives of Spain, they do particularly well in areas with warm winters and hot summers. Many other daffodils won't grow well in the South. Narcissus jonquilla not only grew, it prospered, naturalizing widely in the region.

snippet: Anne Raver Cuttings column on colorful holiday bromeliads and anthuriums; photos (M)
lead_paragraph: IN a radical move, the New York Botanical Garden has dethroned the poinsettia. The hackneyed poinsettia, a tropical plant formally known as Euphorbia pulcherrima, whose cherry red bracts are often mistaken for flowers, was thrust upon the world by Joel Roberts Poinsett in 1825. The first American ambassador to Mexico, he saw it growing wild along a road in southern Mexico and sent it back to his greenhouses in South Carolina to be propagated and given to his friends.

lead_paragraph: AT age 78, Lewis Hill continues his lifelong love affair with berries. As a boy in the 1930's, he would sometimes sneak into the family garden, pick two leaves of lettuce and use them as the bread for a red raspberry sandwich. Now Mr. Hill and his wife, Nancy, own Berry Hill, a small nursery specializing in berries in Greensboro, Vt., and they have all the berries anyone could wish for.
abstract: AT age 78, Lewis Hill continues his lifelong love affair with berries. As a boy in the 1930's, he would sometimes sneak into the family garden, pick two leaves of lettuce and use them as the bread for a red raspberry sandwich. Now Mr. Hill and his wife, Nancy, own Berry Hill, a small nursery specializing in berries in Greensboro, Vt., and they have all the berries anyone could wish for.     Mr. Hill has been growing and selling plants for 55 years on a farm that has been in the family for 200 years. For Mr. Hill, growing up on a small dairy farm during the Depression, college was never an option. He is an avid learner, however, and he and his wife have written 15 books on gardening. His ''Fruits and Berries for the Home Garden'' (Storey Books, 1992) is great for anyone interested in berries.

lead_paragraph: A Saltwater Quandary
abstract: A Saltwater Quandary    Q. My garden is in New Hampshire, right beside salt water. The soil is dry and sandy. Could I grow tall purple sedum there, and if so, what would be the best choice?    A. It depends on what you mean by tall. Sedums are known for tolerance to drought and salty air. But the upright ones, particularly the purple-leaf varieties, have a tendency to flop. Sea wind may keep them compact, but it is likely to flatten very tall varieties like Matrona.

snippet: Roberta Zeff reviews Bonjour Montclair cafe and creperie in Montclair, NJ; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: The coffee-colored awning at Bonjour Montclair is an elegant addition to the cluster of shops around the Watchung Plaza train station in Montclair. It's also an invitation to a tiny, friendly cafe and creperie with flavors of France and the Middle East. Stopping there while waiting for a commuter bus on a recent morning, I tried a lemon crepe ($3.50) so light and intensely lemony, the memory lingered for days and drew me back again and again. The other crepe offerings, like cinnamon apple ($4.50) or ham, cheese and mushrooms ($6.50) have their appeal and tabouleh salad ($5.50) or a prosciutto and mozzarella sandwich are better suited for lunch, but that simple lemon crepe is my new breakfast ideal. And for commuters heading for a bus or train, it's more portable than a crepe loaded down with chunks of strawberry or apple. Mike and DiDi Tuma opened the cafe in early December, encouraged by the raves their crepes drew at a festival in Montclair last year. Every Sunday from last April through September, they sold crepes at festivals, working 18- to 20-hour days. With a young daughter, they wanted a routine. Raised in Nazareth, Israel, Mr. Tuma has worked at a string of restaurants. His mother used to make crepes for him, he said, but he recognized their commercial potential on trips to Paris. ''They have crepes on the street, and people carry them along,'' he said. He spreads batter into a thin circle on a special round griddle, adds the filling and folds it into a rectangle. The sweet crepes get a dusting of powdered sugar and perhaps a drizzle of sauce. That seductive lemon flavor is nothing more than fresh lemon, squeezed over the crepe's warm, eggy surface. Roberta Zeff
abstract: Roberta Zeff reviews Bonjour Montclair cafe and creperie in Montclair, NJ; photo (M)

snippet: Gretchen Kurtz reviews early bird menu at Amanda's restaurant in Hoboken, NJ; logo (M)
lead_paragraph: ''A three-course meal for $10?'' a friend said when I told him about Amanda's early dinner menu. ''What do you get -- soup, rolls, and the check?'' Yes, an early bird special at elegant Amanda's, no joke. From 5 to 6 p.m., Mondays through Saturdays, guests can order from a prix-fixe menu (actually, $10.01) that includes choices among three appetizers (soup, salad or polenta), four entrees (salmon, chicken, steak or pasta) and three desserts (apple strudel, chocolate mousse or Key lime pie). The menu never changes, but that's fine by me: I could eat the polenta with three-cheese sauce followed by the grilled skirt steak every night of the week. And apparently some do. ''Some people come in two or three times a week, then tell me they'd like to try something different,'' said Joyce Flinn, who owns the restaurant with her husband, Eugene. ''I just laugh and think, 'That's what the regular menu is for.' '' The atmosphere at Amanda's is intimate, with two fireplaces and with windows overlooking a well-tended garden. It's the perfect spot for a special occasion, which is to say, the last place you'd expect to find such a bargain. So why do it? ''This is the way we advertise,'' Ms. Flinn said. ''It costs us $10 for the cloth napkins and the basket of bread, but it gets people in the restaurant.'' The hope is they'll return for the regular menu, where entrees alone cost two to three times as much. My only complaint is with the hour, but eating at 5 p.m. is a small price to pay for a small price. Gretchen Kurtz
abstract: Gretchen Kurtz reviews early bird menu at Amanda's restaurant in Hoboken, NJ; logo (M)

lead_paragraph: My recycling bin is purple. It is of modest dimensions -- 8 inches by 11 inches by 12 inches -- but for the past five years it has fulfilled its duty as the final resting place for my glass and plastic bottles, Vietnamese food containers and the occasional can of vegetarian baked beans. But since the city changed the recycling regulations last month and one no longer has to recycle glass and plastic (just metal and paper), my recycling bin has essentially lost its purpose. I can offer it no solace after all its years of service.

lead_paragraph: The fairy tale is often thought to be a simple fantasy, a childish portrait of the world with great villainy vanquished and much happily-ever-aftering. The morals are clear, the virtues plain, the causes of evil transparent. Little Red Riding Hood strays. Sleeping Beauty's father is less than generous. Bluebeard's wife is too curious and her family too incurious. But inner beauty is rewarded. Greed is punished.
abstract: The fairy tale is often thought to be a simple fantasy, a childish portrait of the world with great villainy vanquished and much happily-ever-aftering. The morals are clear, the virtues plain, the causes of evil transparent. Little Red Riding Hood strays. Sleeping Beauty's father is less than generous. Bluebeard's wife is too curious and her family too incurious. But inner beauty is rewarded. Greed is punished.    The impulse may be irresistible: seek the simple cause and the blunt lesson. Such efforts are, as Maria Tatar points out in her new book, ''The Annotated Classic Fairy Tales'' (W. W. Norton), part of a tradition of taming the unruly tale. Over time, the brothers Grimm inserted morals in their tales, even eliminating Rapunzel's premarital pregnancy. The 17th-century French writer, Charles Perrault, whose versions of ''Cinderella'' and ''Puss in Boots'' in his ''Mother Goose Tales'' remain standards, believed in showing that ''virtue is rewarded'' and ''vice is always punished.''

snippet: Forum participants detail their picks for the year's best arts offerings.
lead_paragraph: We asked NYTimes.com readers to list the best and worst of the year in arts. On the whole, it seems that both readers and critics agree that movies like the long-anticipated "Gangs of New York" and albums like Wilco's "Yankee Hotel Foxtrot" deserved superlative rankings. Consensus broke down, however, over Justin Timberlake's debut record "Justified," which some readers loved while others couldn't believe it was even mentioned. There was also division over Bruce Springsteen's "The Rising," which was noted as both best and most overrated.

snippet: Spencer Lee King, 17, says he beat 14-year-old Nonie Drummond to death in her home in Fabius, NY, then set house on fire; says two had engaged in 9-month-long Internet and telephone romance before meeting for first time at her grandfather's isolat...
lead_paragraph: Theirs was a romance born on the Internet and nourished through countless telephone conversations that ran late into the night. Though they had never met face to face, Nonie Drummond, 14, and Spencer Lee King, 17, seemed to have plenty in common: a zeal for MTV, a weakness for junk food and, more than anything, an aching hunger to escape the loneliness and boredom that marked their teenage lives. One day, Nonie boasted to friends, she and the teenager with the long, dirty-blond hair would be married amid the apple and oak trees on her grandfather's 140-acre farm.

abstract: INTERNATIONAL   A3-13    Rumsfeld Headed to India Aiming to Ease War Fears  Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld is on a visit to India intended to put to rest fears of war between India and Pakistan. India, for decades a champion of nonalignment, seeks warmer ties with the United States in hopes of gaining access to military technology and help in dealing with Pakistan. Cooperation between India and the United States has quickened since Sept. 11.   A1    Mr. Rumsfeld crossed the Kuwaiti desert to an American base near Iraq and issued a warning to any state that acquires weapons of mass destruction and plans to strike a bargain with terrorists. Kuwait is the first of three stops in Persian Gulf states that would be critical in mounting any military operation against Iraq.   A13

snippet: William Grimes briefly reviews Olica restaurant in Midtown Manhattan; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: L'Actuel, the Midtown brasserie, has traded in its name, and its identity, for an even more mysterious name, and a warmer, slightly more formal persona. The tables have white tablecloths now. The shiny surfaces have been muted with thick curtains, and large pyramid-shaped lights now cast a soft glow over the dining room. The hamburger, choucroute and snazzy Frenchified tapas dishes have been shown the door. lead_paragraph: COLEMAN-Enid Anderson. Formerly of Bedford Village, NY, died peacefully Friday, February 1, at the age of 92. She was a dedicated, devoted and determined wife and mother: a discerning woman of searing intellect, who also made the best apple pie in the world. She lived through and for her family: her husband Randolph, her children Esther, John and Virginia, and her grandchildren. Those who survive her now feel her loss. Burial is private. Donations in her memory may be made to any animal welfare organization.

snippet: Zhang Yang's film tells the story of Jia Hongsheng, a rising Chinese movie star of the early 1990's whose career was derailed by drug problems and mental illness. If Mr. Zhang's subject matter is, to some degree at least, quintessentially American...
lead_paragraph: ''Quitting,'' a new film by Zhang Yang, tells the story of Jia Hongsheng, a rising Chinese movie star of the early 1990's whose career was derailed by drug problems and mental illness. In outline, Mr. Jia's story might have, for American audiences, a wearying familiarity: addiction and recovery, especially when it involves celebrities, is so ubiquitous a theme as to seem like a touchstone of our culture. And at least superficially, ''Quitting'' suggests that Beijing, where the movie takes place, is not so different from New York or Los Angeles. It is a big, impersonal city that draws ambitious young people from the provinces and subjects them to temptation, loneliness and danger.
abstract: Zhang Yang's film tells the story of Jia Hongsheng, a rising Chinese movie star of the early 1990's whose career was derailed by drug problems and mental illness. If Mr. Zhang's subject matter is, to some degree at least, quintessentially American, his approach to storytelling might be called Iranian. The role of Jia Hongsheng is played by the actor himself, and nearly all of the other characters in the film, from his parents (who are, like their son, professional actors) to his fellow inmates at a psychiatric hospital, likewise play themselves. This technique has been used, to extraordinary effect, by Iranian filmmakers like Abbas Kiarostami (most famously in "Close Up") and Samira Makhmalbaf (in "The Apple"). It sounds exploitive, but it is really the opposite. Somehow, inviting people to recreate moments of vulnerability and confusion affirms their dignity rather than stripping it away. — A. O. Scott

lead_paragraph: Q. I have been a PC user since 1984. Until recently it has been my understanding that Mac files and Windows files are incompatible. Is that still true? If I should buy an iMac, could I still exchange files with people who use Windows 98 or XP?
abstract: Q. I have been a PC user since 1984. Until recently it has been my understanding that Mac files and Windows files are incompatible. Is that still true? If I should buy an iMac, could I still exchange files with people who use Windows 98 or XP?    A. Although it is not a completely seamless situation, compatibility between Windows-based PC's and Macintosh computers has come a long way over the last 18 years. Macintosh computers have been able to recognize PC-formatted floppy and Zip disks for several years and can open files in basic text and graphics formats without additional software.

Nature may have been suckered into an unaccustomed haste by the sudden warm weather, but it's committed now; no going back, not even on a day like yesterday, when the temperature fell well below normal and the rain, though needed, seemed a little bit unfair.

lead_paragraph: Q. I do all of the regular maintenance suggested, like defragging and disk cleanup, to keep my Windows system tuned up, but I find it still gets slower over time. Why is this?
abstract: Q. I do all of the regular maintenance suggested, like defragging and disk cleanup, to keep my Windows system tuned up, but I find it still gets slower over time. Why is this?    A. Regular maintenance can help keep a computer working quickly for longer stretches of time, but most systems begin to slow down noticeably after several months of steady use. Over time the Windows operating system handles a lot of information, but much of it is temporary. Old settings, data and other outdated system information that Windows has but no longer needs can gum up the works and slow things down. Bits of software used by the operating system can also become damaged or corrupted over time and by crashes, which can contribute to slowness.

lead_paragraph: THE GOLD-THREADED DRESS. By Carolyn Marsden. Candlewick. $13.99. (Ages 8 to 12) Oy, who comes from Thailand, is frustrated and lonely. Her teachers call her Olivia. No one knows where Thailand is. The most popular girl in the class tells Oy to bring her beautiful silk dancing dress to the playground for the others to try on if she wants to be in their club. Here's a fine novel for early independent readers that conveys lots of information -- about Thailand and making friends -- in a familiar kind of classroom story.
abstract: THE GOLD-THREADED DRESS. By Carolyn Marsden. Candlewick. $13.99. (Ages 8 to 12) Oy, who comes from Thailand, is frustrated and lonely. Her teachers call her Olivia. No one knows where Thailand is. The most popular girl in the class tells Oy to bring her beautiful silk dancing dress to the playground for the others to try on if she wants to be in their club. Here's a fine novel for early independent readers that conveys lots of information -- about Thailand and making friends -- in a familiar kind of classroom story.    THE DIFFERENCE BETWEEN BABIES AND COOKIES. By Mary Hanson. Illustrated by Debbie Tilley. Silver Whistle/Harcourt. $16. (Ages 3 to 7) The narrator is a sensible girl who has thought carefully about some of the well-intentioned things her mother told her before the new baby came. For example, Mom said, ''Babies' cheeks are as rosy as apples.'' But she added, ''You can't give your sister to your teacher.'' Fun to talk about if the situation applies, or might apply, or just because the ideas and illustrations are amusing and insightful.    HUSH. By Jacqueline Woodson. Putnam. $15.99. (Ages 12 and up) Toswiah Green was a happy girl who lived in Denver. That was a lifetime ago, because now she is Evie Thomas, living in a small apartment in a strange city with her renamed and unhappy family. They are in a witness protection plan. A smoothly plotted and engrossing novel.    THE BROKEN CAT. Written and illustrated by Lynne Rae Perkins. Greenwillow. $15.95. (Ages 5 and up) Mom, Aunt Cookie and Grandma go to the vet with Andy and his cat, Frank, who is sick. They distract the worried boy with the elaborate story of Mom's broken arm, until the vet is ready for them. The illustrations dealing with recuperation show Mom and Frank in parallel panels. It's a cleverly designed story that is both instructive and reassuring.    BREAK A LEG: The Kids' Guide to Acting and Stagecraft. By Lise Friedman. Workman. $14.95. (Ages 10 and up) Going to summer camp? Putting on a show? Just dreaming? Here's a whole lot of accessibly organized information about acting, using a cast of 12 young professionals in photographs demonstrating everything from warm-up exercises to falling backward. Lots of definitions, advice and resources.    SEA-CAT AND DRAGON KING. By Angela Carter. Illustrated by Eva Tatcheva. Bloomsbury. $12.95. (Ages 4 to 8) The Dragon King overheard gossipy sea creatures marveling at how beautiful Sea-Cat was in the rainbow catsuit his mother made him and grew jealous. A paean to clever mothers everywhere. It is the only original story Carter, who died in 1992, wrote for children.    BLACK IS BROWN IS TAN. By Arnold Adoff. Illustrated by Emily Arnold McCully. Amistad/HarperCollins. $15.95. (Ages 4 to 8) The poem about a happy, hugging interracial family was published in 1973, and has been reissued with new watercolor illustrations.    CRISPIN: The Cross of Lead. By Avi. Hyperion. $15.99. (Ages 8 to 12) Crispin joins forces with a juggler in the author's 50th book, an adventure story set in medieval England.

lead_paragraph: It was the goose farm that gave it away. A news release for ''Resa Fantastiskt Mystisk'' recounts the story of this recently rediscovered masterwork by the great 19th-century Swedish playwright Lars Mattsun. But the mention of his family's struggling goose-breeding business and the references in the program to Mattsun's Fruit Period are definite hints that he may not exist. At the end of ''Resa,'' which is part of the New York International Fringe Festival, audiences will be glad that Matt Almos and his eight co-writers (including most of the cast) invented him.

snippet: Some software companies are reducing amount of free technical support they offer to customers, leaving many users to fend for themselves or pay fees that range from nominal to fairly steep; Microsoft is bucking trend, promising unlimited free supp...
lead_paragraph: FOR 14 years, computer users who bought software by Dantz, a manufacturer of backup programs, received unlimited free technical support by phone or by e-mail. No longer. Earlier this year, Dantz began restricting its free assistance to just 30 days after purchase. Customers who buy an upgrade of a Dantz program get no free help at all. Depending on the product, both types of customers will have to pay either $39.95 or $69.95 per incident to talk to someone who can help solve their problem.

snippet: Marilyn Stasio reviews following books: Breakout by Richard Stark; A Well-Known Secret by Jim Fusilli; Gone Tomorrow by Cynthia Harrod-Eagles; The Edge of Doom by Amanda Cross; and The Prince of Deadly Weapons by Boston Teran; drawing (M)
lead_paragraph: It takes a cunning mind to break out of jail. But it takes a truly twisted mind to break out of one jail only to break into another fortress from which, perforce, the break-in artist must subsequently break out -- and then repeat the entire exercise. We have met this devious mind and it is a creation of Richard Stark, who applies his great wit and dexterous mental skills to a series of such ingenious exits and entrances in (what else?) BREAKOUT (Mysterious Press/Warner, $23.95). The mastermind of these exploits is, of course, the career criminal known as Parker, as cool a customer as ever tunneled under a library, through the foundations of an armory and into a jewelry vault -- which happens to be one of the more challenging misadventures that Parker gets up to in this jampacked plot.

lead_paragraph: Sometimes you have to work a bit to find the Gotham moon, as it gets sandwiched between buildings. But when it's at its fullest, it lights up the night sky like a Broadway premiere. Many New Yorkers follow its waxing and waning with interest; some hear the voice of Frank Sinatra singing about flying there or of Neil Armstrong talking about his small step. Its fullness near the beginning of fall is a time of celebration for many ethnic groups, among them Chinese, who have the harvest moon festival; Jews, who observe the festival of Sukkot; and Koreans, who have Chusok, their Thanksgiving.

snippet: Jean-Louis Gassee resigns as chief executive of Be Inc (S)
lead_paragraph: Jean-Louis Gassée, founder and chief executive of the operating system company Be Inc., resigned on Monday. The company, which sold its technology assets and intellectual property to Palm for $11 million in August, made innovative software that was nonetheless unable to find a market. Be struggled for more than 10 years to create an operating system to compete with Apple, Linux and Microsoft. Mr. Gassée suggested in a statement that Be was considering an antitrust suit against Microsoft, but provided no details. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

lead_paragraph: THIS week a report from the InsightExpress research firm shed some fascinating light on the high-tech buying habits of the college-bound. These days, parents aren't as involved as you might expect in helping their teenagers decide which computer, MP3 player, digital camera or palmtop to buy. Up to 76 percent of the time, students decide which models to buy without parental help (or parental interference, depending on how you look at it). And 40 percent of the time, the students even pay for the stuff themselves.

snippet: In general, few people are less interested in predicting the future of technology than I am. The high-tech business is inherently unpredictable--almost random. Just as nobody in 1980 could have seen Microsoft or the Internet coming, so nobody can ...
lead_paragraph: In general, few people are less interested in predicting the future of technology than I am. The high-tech business is inherently unpredictable--almost random. Just as nobody in 1980 could have seen Microsoft or the Internet coming, so nobody can imagine whatever huge development is being hatched in a garage somewhere at this very moment. Whatever any pundit tells you about technology even five years from now should be taken with a grain of salt the size of Canada. In fact, the whole exercise should be considered slightly less scientific than the horoscope column at the back of a teen fashion magazine.

snippet: Wilson Rothman Basics column reviews new generation of external hard drives, sleek and space-saving devices that can store more than 40 gigabytes of information; they can be used for extra storage or backing up entire system; drives are simple to ...
lead_paragraph: IF you live in an apartment, you must occasionally get the urge to knock down a wall, boot your neighbor and double the size of your place. Maybe it is human nature or Manifest Destiny, or that you simply have too much stuff. There is no painless way to expand your personal space, but if your storage problem extends to a PC overflowing with MP3 songs, PowerPoint presentations and digital video, an external hard drive may be the solution.

snippet: Photo of two-wheel Scoot, battery-powered scooter that can be carried on one's back (Currents: California)
lead_paragraph: Hydrogen fuel-cell motors are the rage at the North American International Auto Show in Detroit. The new technology will power the two-wheel Scoot, right, a scooter you can also carry on your back. The prototype, designed by Yves Behar and Johan Liden of fuseproject, a San Francisco-based industrial design company, is aimed at urbanites in congested cities. The scooter is made of cast aluminum and carbon fiber and will be powered by a fuel-cell battery. (Scoot is awaiting patent.) Fuseproject expects the scooter to cost about $500. Mr. Behar founded the firm in 1997, after stints at frogdesign and lunar design in San Francisco, where he did projects for Apple and Hewlett-Packard. The prototype of Scoot will be seen at the Chicago Athenaeum Good Design Award 2001 exhibition from March 8 to April 30.

lead_paragraph: MANHATTAN: PARKING FINES TO RISE TO UP TO $105 Fines on some parking violations will rise next Tuesday, almost doubling for certain offenses. The violations that will have the higher fines generally involve violations of no-stopping or no-standing rules, said Sam Miller, a spokesman for the City Department of Finance. Alternate-side-of-the-street and meter-violation fines will not go up. The fines, which are currently $55, will be going up to $85 or $105, depending on the violation. "Most of these fines have not been increased since 1975," Mr. Miller said. The state authorized the city to increase fines in July. (AP)

snippet: Footnotes to article on Los Angeles home of Cameron Silver; photos (M)
lead_paragraph: 1. Before opening Decades, his trendsetting vintage boutique in Los Angeles, in 1997, Cameron Silver traveled around North America singing German cabaret, and while on tour, refused to speak during the day to protect his voice. To amuse himself on those silent days, Silver combed thrift stores for old Pucci ties, and was ultimately inspired to make vintage clothes a career. ''I bought three things,'' he recalls of his ''Eureka!'' shopping moment in 1996. ''A Rudi Gernreich kabuki dress, an apple-green Trigère spring coat and a 1970's navy YSL suit.'' Nowadays, Silver says, he's too old to go thrift shopping, but he still hand-picks every item of 60's and 70's style that he sells at Decades (8214 Melrose Avenue, Los Angeles) and at Barneys New York (660 Madison Avenue).

snippet: Journeys article on 36-hour trip to Rochester, NY; photos; maps (M)
lead_paragraph: THOUGH in New York State, Rochester is geographically and temperamentally closer to Cleveland than it is to Manhattan, with a decidedly Midwestern character. (In 1993, a survey by California State University at Fresno declared Rochester residents to be the ''most helpful'' among those in the 36 United States cities studied.) The local cuisine revolves around deep frying, charbroiling, hot dogs (called simply ''hots'') and hot sauces; the accent is flat and nasal. Culturally, the biggest force is not a place, but a man, George Eastman, responsible for the town's cinematic and photographic history and for endowing, among other institutions, local universities and the acclaimed Eastman School of Music. Add to the mix a striking natural environment -- the Erie Canal, the north-flowing Genesee River, Lake Ontario and farmland just minutes outside of town -- and the result is a pleasant blend of big city, small town and countryside. J. R. ROMANKO
abstract: Journeys article on 36-hour trip to Rochester, NY; photos; maps (M)

lead_paragraph: DEEP in Red Hook, Brooklyn, down Van Brunt Street, where you can smell the salt off New York Bay, there's a new diner, the Hope & Anchor. It's a neighborhood place in a neighborhood that doesn't have a lot of people, and it needs to serve a number of purposes at once.
abstract: DEEP in Red Hook, Brooklyn, down Van Brunt Street, where you can smell the salt off New York Bay, there's a new diner, the Hope & Anchor. It's a neighborhood place in a neighborhood that doesn't have a lot of people, and it needs to serve a number of purposes at once.    It's a standard-issue diner breakfast spot -- eggs served all day -- and a purveyor of lunchtime sandwiches to local artists, homesteaders and layabouts. It's also an art-world dinner spot, serving would-be Basquiats luxe tuna steaks on the cheap, and a wings-and-burgers joint for those on their way home from work or on their way out to a bar. It ought to be the sort of place where you could trade a painting, or your services as a plumber, for a nice dish of monkfish.

lead_paragraph: A year after the Taliban departed in tatters, the extraordinary has become the ordinary here and citizens generally revel in what is for many the distant but distinct opportunity to lead normal lives.
abstract: A year after the Taliban departed in tatters, the extraordinary has become the ordinary here and citizens generally revel in what is for many the distant but distinct opportunity to lead normal lives.    A family of returning refugees lives in the house where a group of suspected Al Qaeda members kept a list of flight schools in the United States. Teenagers play pickup basketball in the park where Kabul residents mutilated the bodies of pro-Taliban militants. The cellphone has replaced the turban as the city's leading power symbol. An estimated 2,000 mostly Western aid workers have replaced the hundreds of Pakistani and Arab militants who lived here.

lead_paragraph: Q. How can I find out whether any Easter eggs are hidden in my software?
abstract: Q.  How can I find out whether any Easter eggs are hidden in my software?    A.  For those who have never stumbled across one when using a computer, an Easter egg is a wry surprise from the software's programmers that is not found in the user's manual. It can be a secret message that pops up after a series of actions in a program, for example, or an animated character that appears onscreen when a certain series of keys is pressed. (Easter eggs are usually whimsical or humorous, although not all are in the best of taste.)

snippet: Kosher cooking has a bright new venue at the Jewish Community Center, which has just opened at 334 Amsterdam Avenue (76th Street).
lead_paragraph: Kosher cooking has a bright new venue at the Jewish Community Center, which has just opened at 334 Amsterdam Avenue (76th Street). Starting Feb. 4, chefs from restaurants on the Upper West Side, including Neil Annis of Marika, Sarabeth Levine of Sarabeth's and Gennaro Piccone of Gennaro, will present a series of demonstrations there on adapting their recipes in accordance with kosher law ($275 for the series, $50 per class for members, or $335 and $60 for nonmembers). There's a kosher teaching kitchen with gas range tops, ovens, refrigerators and dishwashers — two of each, for meat and dairy preparations — and a full program of classes, including some for children and families. The director of the center's cooking school, Einav Gefen (far left, with Ms. Levine), was a chef in Israel, studied cooking at Peter Kump's (now the Institute for Culinary Education), and was an intern at Daniel. Some instructors, like Anita Jacobson, also teach at the Institute for Culinary Education. For information: (646) 505-4379.
abstract: Kosher cooking has a bright new venue at the Jewish Community Center, which has just opened at 334 Amsterdam Avenue (76th Street).

snippet: Pomegranates are being used in variety of new beauty products, including exfoliating scrubs and fragrances; photo (Pulse column) (M)
lead_paragraph: The pomegranate, one of the world's oldest fruits, has become the beauty industry's newest darling. Its slightly astringent properties, hydrating powers and light scent can now be found in a variety of products, among them exfoliating scrubs and fragrances. This month, Origins introduces Pomegranate Polish, above, a red body scrub intended to smooth and refresh winter-weary skin. Murad puts pomegranate in both sunscreen ($23) and self-tanner ($21), and Bottoms Up combines it with Champagne in a hair shine rinse ($16.50), all at Sephora. Santa Maria Novella offers a moisturizing bath soap ($38 for a set of four bars, at www.eluxury.com), while beComing makes a Clean Gesture hydrating foam cleanser ($12 at the Avon Spa). And Comme des Garçons uses top notes of pomegranate in its White perfume ($60 at Barneys New York), and so does Fresh in its scented Pomegranate and Anise Index candle ($40 at Fresh). The profusion of this ''apple of many seeds'' might almost be enough to lure Persephone out of the underworld again -- just in time for spring.
abstract: Pomegranates are being used in variety of new beauty products, including exfoliating scrubs and fragrances; photo (Pulse column) (M)

The poster announced a 1986 conference that dealt with historic preservation, and Red Hook seems to have taken the concept to heart. The village center with its red-brick storefronts, 90 miles up the Hudson Valley from New York, still has the feel of a Norman Rockwell painting.

snippet: Editorial says Pres Bush's much-anticipated speech on July 9 needs to lay out vigorous agenda for reform to tackle plague of accounting and insider-trading abuse; says he cannot be blamed for current crisis of confidence in American financial syst...
lead_paragraph: George W. Bush is the first president with an M.B.A., and that training should make him especially well equipped to handle the growing anxiety over corporate scandals. Indeed, with questions still lingering over a 1990 sale by Mr. Bush of $848,560 worth of stock in a company on whose board he sat, the president should be eager to tackle the plague of accounting and insider-trading abuse. Yet the Bush team has been so slow to react to the need for higher standards of disclosure and tougher regulation of business practices that even Congress has moved fast enough to seize the initiative. When the president addresses these issues on Tuesday in a much-anticipated speech in New York City, he needs to lay out a vigorous agenda for reform.
abstract: Editorial says Pres Bush's much-anticipated speech on July 9 needs to lay out vigorous agenda for reform to tackle plague of accounting and insider-trading abuse; says he cannot be blamed for current crisis of confidence in American financial system, but it is up to him to set tone of new debate; says rather than punish few bad apples, as he puts it, he should change ground rules to restore confidence of investors and of American citizens who work in the system and invest in it

snippet: "[Pierre] Omidyar was doing what every other smart tech person within a hundred-mile radius of San Jose was doing: obsessing about the Internet . . ."
lead_paragraph: Pierre Omidyar was born in Paris in 1967 to a French-Iranian family that placed a premium on intellectual pursuits. Omidyar's parents had been sent to France by their families as young adults to get a better education than was available in Iran in the early 1960s. Omidyar's father attended medical school; his mother studied linguistics at the Sorbonne. They met for the first time in their adopted land-an encounter that was all but inevitable, given the size of the city's Iranian community—and eventually married. When Pierre, their only child, was six, they emigrated to the United States so that his father could begin a urology residency at Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore.
abstract: "[Pierre] Omidyar was doing what every other smart tech person within a hundred-mile radius of San Jose was doing: obsessing about the Internet . . ."

snippet: Walter Kirn article on perception of New York City in American hinterland; says New York was place of dread when he left it for Montana in 1990 but gradually became city of great allure, all shattered by events of Sept 11, 2001; photo (L)
lead_paragraph: When I left New York for Montana in 1990, I wasn't planning to stay away forever, ending up as one of those sad, displaced sophisticates who can't eat a corned beef sandwich at the truck stop without telling everybody sitting nearby that real New York Reubens use Swiss cheese, not Velveeta -- and by the way, did you know I sang on Broadway once? No, I was merely waiting for prices to drop. Having moved to the city from the Midwestern farm belt, I believed that the prices of basic urban commodities like restaurant meals, movie tickets and top-floor lofts obeyed the same boom-and-bust rhythms as pork and soy. The trick, I believed, was to take what little remained of the fair money I'd squandered on rides and candy during my feverish five years in Manhattan, let it compound in a passbook savings account and pray for a drought that would devastate Greenwich Village. In the meantime, I'd visit three or four times a year -- for work, and to scout out the town house I'd one day buy from some ruined gallery owner or wine importer.
abstract: Walter Kirn article on perception of New York City in American hinterland; says New York was place of dread when he left it for Montana in 1990 but gradually became city of great allure, all shattered by events of Sept 11, 2001; photo (L)

lead_paragraph: Working With Phyllo Dough
abstract: Working With Phyllo Dough    Q. Every time I try to make something with phyllo dough it dries out while I'm working with it. I unfold the sheets of dough on a countertop and cover them with plastic wrap, but the dough still gets too dry. Is there a secret to keeping the dough moist?    A. Phyllo dough (also known as filo dough) comes from Greek and Middle Eastern cuisines. It consists of paper-thin sheets that traditionally are brushed with butter and stacked, often interspersed with layers of sweet or savory filling. The dough can be tricky to work with because the delicate, flexible sheets become brittle when exposed to air.

snippet: clockwork: tim
lead_paragraph: OF all the dreams of science fiction, time travel is the giddiest. To escape time is to escape everything -- history, regret and, above all, death. Fed up with Victorian England? Speed to the distant future, as in H. G. Wells's 1895 classic, ''The Time Machine.'' Miserable as an adult? Fly back to your own happier high-school days, as in two of this fall's new television shows. Angry at the end of life? Then choose cryonics, the most immediately available, if certainly the most inelegant, of time machines.

snippet: Thomas L Friedman Op-Ed column says corporate malfeasance can be found all around world, but what distinguishes American capitalism from most other countries is American system's ability to expose, punish, regulate and ultimately reform excesses; ...
lead_paragraph: Several years ago an Indian journalist friend of mine, who was working in Indonesia, remarked to me that corruption in the Indonesian bureaucracy was so endemic that when he paid a bribe to renew his residency permit, the Indonesian official he paid off actually gave him a receipt for his bribe so my friend could be reimbursed by his newspaper. For anyone who has worked abroad, such stories are not unusual. But they are also a useful prism for examining the epidemic of corporate cheating now wracking America.
abstract: Thomas L Friedman Op-Ed column says corporate malfeasance can be found all around world, but what distinguishes American capitalism from most other countries is American system's ability to expose, punish, regulate and ultimately reform excesses; says what foreigners envy is America's alphabet soup of regulatory agencies--same bureaucracy that Pres Bush is so scornful of; says Bush should appreciate that so much of America's moral authority to lead world derives from decency of government and its bureacurats, and example they set for others (M)

snippet: Adam Cohen Editorial Observer recalls great funeral industry scam exposed by Jessica Mitford 39 years ago, one in series of corporate scandals that are have been part of American history since Yazoo land fraud of 1795; notes some of conclusions of...
lead_paragraph: The high point -- make that the low point -- of ''The American Way of Death'' is Jessica Mitford's account of a friend's attempt to bury a relative without spending a fortune. When the friend asked for an inexpensive redwood coffin, the funeral home agreed at first. But the salesman called back to say the deceased was too tall, and she had to buy a coffin that cost $100 more. When Ms. Mitford's friend balked, the salesman responded, ''Oh, all right, we'll use the redwood one, but we'll have to cut off his feet.''
abstract: Adam Cohen Editorial Observer recalls great funeral industry scam exposed by Jessica Mitford 39 years ago, one in series of corporate scandals that are have been part of American history since Yazoo land fraud of 1795; notes some of conclusions of Mitford's book The American Way of Death, which apply to this year's corporate scandals: never underestimate corporate greed, sometimes it is not just few 'bad apples,' and reform comes slowly

snippet: Article on 36-hour getaway to Concord, Mass; photos; map (M)
lead_paragraph: CONCORD is no Colonial Williamsburg. Although it was the birthplace of both the Revolutionary War and the Concord grape and home to an impressive collection of 19th-century literary and intellectual powerhouses, it's got things on its mind besides reliving the past. While downtown Concord has historic houses, funky West Concord is an eclectic tie-dye village with fabulous bakeries, a brewery, a five-and-dime straight out of the 1950's and a famous pottery store (the Potting Shed, known for its reproductions of Dedham pottery). Concord has learned to thrive on an ever-shifting combination of old and new, respecting the past while relaxing with a latte. As Emerson said, ''Nothing is at last sacred but the integrity of your own mind.''
abstract: Article on 36-hour getaway to Concord, Mass; photos; map (M)

lead_paragraph: I went to junior high during those last awkward years when girls were segregated into home-ec classes and boys into shop. It was the early 70's, and some of us had been reared in the spirit of ''Free to Be You and Me,'' so the whole separatist system already seemed antique and faintly comical. In sewing class, where we concocted unsightly tote bags, I earned a D-plus, but I didn't much care. In cooking class, we learned how to make, for our future husbands, English-muffin pizzas and mock apple pie with Ritz crackers, though I think even we knew that adults didn't serve those particular dishes to one another. A lot of the girls spent the hour passing nasty notes and snarfing hunks of brown sugar straight from the canister. I used to stare at the teacher and wonder where she got the muumuus she always wore to class.
abstract: I went to junior high during those last awkward years when girls were segregated into home-ec classes and boys into shop. It was the early 70's, and some of us had been reared in the spirit of ''Free to Be You and Me,'' so the whole separatist system already seemed antique and faintly comical. In sewing class, where we concocted unsightly tote bags, I earned a D-plus, but I didn't much care. In cooking class, we learned how to make, for our future husbands, English-muffin pizzas and mock apple pie with Ritz crackers, though I think even we knew that adults didn't serve those particular dishes to one another. A lot of the girls spent the hour passing nasty notes and snarfing hunks of brown sugar straight from the canister. I used to stare at the teacher and wonder where she got the muumuus she always wore to class.    Still, at least it was only home ec, the hour of the day you more or less expected to squander. At least we weren't being offered, say, Science for Girls, on the specious theory that girls learn differently than boys do and that knowledge cannot transcend gender. At least we weren't being told that boys were a tribulation and a distraction, before which we more civilized creatures were helpless. At least we had the consolation of dimly suspecting that such classes were headed for the In-Sink-Erator of history.

snippet: Tovah Martin Cuttings column on trying to rescue her garden after hailstorm; drawing (M)
lead_paragraph: NO one saw it coming. Not the weather service, the farmer down the street or the songbirds that are usually attuned to natural disasters predicted that golf ball-size hail would be pelting my garden on a sweltering Sunday in mid-June. It began with brutal winds. Halfway through, the rain changed direction to horizontal, and then hail pelted down bushels of immense and weighty stones for the grand finale. Worst of all, it went on and on. The repercussions pretty much ruined the rest of summer for a lot of gardeners.

lead_paragraph: In a new open-air mall built amid the fast-food restaurants and chain stores in suburban Orange County, Calif., bird song fills the air and the soft lapping of ocean waves can be heard in the distance. The sounds may be piped in through an outdoor speaker system, but they seem fitting at the Camp, a shopping center dedicated to the great outdoors.
abstract: In a new open-air mall built amid the fast-food restaurants and chain stores in suburban Orange County, Calif., bird song fills the air and the soft lapping of ocean waves can be heard in the distance. The sounds may be piped in through an outdoor speaker system, but they seem fitting at the Camp, a shopping center dedicated to the great outdoors.     The 50,000-square-foot mall, which opened in the spring, is the brainchild of Shaheen Sadeghi, a former fashion designer, and his wife, Linda, who also worked in fashion. Nearly 10 years after they opened their first project, the LAB Anti-Mall, a shopping center that catered to Generation X youth, the couple went across the street to build the Camp. That mall is a kind of fantasy marketplace for what Mr. Sadeghi calls human-powered sports: kayaking, rock climbing and snowboarding.

snippet: Some restaurants are allowing dessert-lovers to compile their own assortments of mini-sweets.
lead_paragraph: Some restaurants are allowing dessert-lovers to compile their own assortments of mini-sweets. At Théo, 325 Spring Street (Greenwich Street), the desserts, in identical little cups, are layered treats combining cake, mousse, cream, fruit and sauces. The selections include apple crumble, banana-banana, Jell-O and cream, and pistachio jubilee. Each is $4. At Compass, 208 West 70th Street, the pastry chef, Jehangir Mehta, offers his desserts, including chocolate-banana flan, lemon-grass panna cotta, and basil cake with mint sorbet in miniature for $4.50 each. And at Isla, 39 Downing Street (Bedford Street), a pick-and-choose tasting plate can be ordered for the table, $9 a person.
abstract: Some restaurants are allowing dessert-lovers to compile their own assortments of mini-sweets.

snippet: Laurel Thatcher Ulrich Op-Ed article on origins of Thanksgiving, America's most authentic national holiday; holds Thanksgiving's authenticity derives from way it renews, year after year, dream of American abundance; recalls description of Thanksgi...
lead_paragraph: As I unbag a free-range turkey bought at my local grocery store, I think of the description of a Thanksgiving dinner in a now-forgotten novel. ''Northwood, A Tale of New England,'' published in Boston in 1827, launched Sarah Josepha Hale's literary career. More than three decades later, as the influential editor of Godey's Lady's Book, she helped persuade Abraham Lincoln to declare Thanksgiving a national holiday.

snippet: Josephine Humphreys article on exotic animals that live in unique environment of Galapagos Islands; photos; map (special section, The Sophisticated Traveler) (part 2 of 2-part section) (M)
lead_paragraph: My panguero was a lean, cool Ecuadorean in sunglasses and baseball cap. Part cowboy, part gondolier, he drove standing up, one hand on the outboard throttle of the panga, a pontoon dinghy for ferrying tourists in and out of the small harbors of the Galápagos Islands. He didn't say much; he left the talking to our naturalist guide Dora, but he knew what we'd come to see. The Venecia Islets are something to behold, scattered lava formations off the coast of Cerro Dragon on Santa Cruz, central island of the Galápagos, made when the islands were spat from the Pacific in fiery chunks a few million years ago. Some of the islets are purely rock while others bristle with shrubs and candelabra cactus. Mangroves fringe the lagoons. This is a place of eerie beauty -- but on the first day of a weeklong cruise in the archipelago, we were, like most visitors to the Galápagos, intent on something else.
abstract: Josephine Humphreys article on exotic animals that live in unique environment of Galapagos Islands; photos; map (special section, The Sophisticated Traveler) (part 2 of 2-part section) (M)

snippet: "From Dieppe we drove to Cany-Barville, of which I remember only two things: a vast and watery soup pullulating with some non-British grain or pulse; and being sent out on my first foreign morning for the newspaper."
lead_paragraph: Ifirst went to France in the summer of 1959 at the age of thirteen. My pre-adolescence had been car-free and island-bound; now there stood in front of our house a gun-metal-grey Triumph Mayflower, bought secondhand, suddenly affordable thanks to a £200 grant from Great Aunt Edie. It struck me then - as any car would have done - as deeply handsome, if perhaps a little too boxy and sharp-edged for true elegance.; last year, in a poll of British autophiles, it was voted one of the ten ugliest cars ever built. Registration plate RTW1, red leather upholstery, walnut dashboard, no radio, and a blue metal RAC badge on the front. (The RAC man, portly and moustachioed, with heavy patched boots and a subservient manner, had arrived to enrol us. His first, preposterous question to my father - 'Now, sir, how many cars have you got?' - passed into quiet family myth.) That cars were intended not just for safe commuting but also for perilous voyage was endorsed the Triumph's subtitle, and further its illustrative hubcaps: at their centre was an emblematic boss depicting, in blue and red enamel, a Mercator projection of the globe.
abstract: "From Dieppe we drove to Cany-Barville, of which I remember only two things: a vast and watery soup pullulating with some non-British grain or pulse; and being sent out on my first foreign morning for the newspaper."

We were never disappointed.

snippet: Most home cooks need only one heavy Dutch oven, and one usually lasts a lifetime.
lead_paragraph: Most home cooks need only one heavy Dutch oven, and one usually lasts a lifetime. Mine — more than 50 years old — belonged to my mother. But I am sorely tempted to buy one by Staub, a French brand adored by top chefs and now available in America. These casseroles "conduct heat beautifully, and yet they're elegant enough to go into the dining room," said David Waltuck of Chanterelle, which uses them. The black matte finish gives the pots a cast-iron look, but heavy enamel actually covers the cast iron. The pots are rustproof and need no seasoning. The lids have brass knobs, and studs on the underside encourage cooking juices to condense onto the surface of the food, automatically basting it. The pots range from one cup to 12 1/2 quarts. Sur La Table in Manhasset, N.Y., and around the country sells the cookware, which is $29.95 for the one-cup version to $235.95 for an eight-quart size. It can be ordered from (800) 243-0852, www.surlatable.com or from Staub, which carries the entire line and whose prices are slightly lower. Green, blue, yellow and purple casseroles are available from Staub, (866) 782-8287 and can be special-ordered from Sur La Table.
abstract: Most home cooks need only one heavy Dutch oven, and one usually lasts a lifetime.

snippet: New developments in portable music recordings discussed; capacity has expanded so entire music library can be portable; article includes review of 'jukeboxes' that hold 20 gigabytes, or roughly 4,000 songs, running about 300 hours; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: IF you have been buying CD's regularly for the last 10 or 15 years, then you probably have what is politely termed an organizational problem. Any attempts at alphabetical arrangement are foiled when you bring home another couple of discs, and besides, filing Mozart after Motorhead always feels a little strange. And when you grab a few CD's to take with you in the car, on a plane or to the beach, you are not only subjecting your precious music to the elements, you are also being forced to pick favorites. You may be in the mood for Public Enemy at 9 a.m., but who's to say you will still want to hear it after lunch?

snippet: David Pogue column assessing Palm's new Zire, stripped-down and simplified palmtop organizer priced at only $99; drawing; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: AT this point in the information age, it has become clear that the high-tech industry operates according to certain unwritten laws. For example, there is Sony's Law: Smaller always costs more. There is Symantec's Law: Good tech support is hard to find. And above all, there's Microsoft's Law: Each version of a product must offer a longer feature list than its predecessor, even if the overall result isn't an improvement.

snippet: Al Gore Op-Ed article says there has always been debate over American destiny between those who believe they are entitled by status to govern and those who believe people are sovereign, and that distinction remains as strong as ever; urges voters ...
lead_paragraph: There has always been a debate over the destiny of this nation between those who believed they were entitled to govern because of their station in life, and those who believed that the people were sovereign. That distinction remains as strong as ever today. In every race this November, the question voters must answer is, How do we make sure that political power is used for the benefit of the many, rather than the few?
abstract: Al Gore Op-Ed article says there has always been debate over American destiny between those who believe they are entitled by status to govern and those who believe people are sovereign, and that distinction remains as strong as ever; urges voters this November to take government back from the greedy; adds that Pres Bush ought to be leading effort against corporate wrongdoers (M)

snippet: Many Chinese dishes cook in minutes, but the trimming, chopping, seasoning and marinating you have to do beforehand can take considerable time.
lead_paragraph: Many Chinese dishes cook in minutes, but the trimming, chopping, seasoning and marinating you have to do beforehand can take considerable time. For those seeking shortcuts, Deluxe Food Market, 79 Elizabeth Street (Hester Street), sells seasoned and marinated meat, poultry and seafood that is ready for the steamer or wok. It's the newest and largest of a chain of Chinatown markets. Marinated rib-eye, spareribs with black beans, chicken with mushrooms, ground pork with preserved vegetables, sole with garlic and ginger, sea bass with black beans and marinated frogs' legs are just a few of the dozens of choices. Most are $2.29 to $5.99 a pound, and yield extremely tasty results. Pigs' ears and tripe, which are complicated to clean and trim, are also available, seasoned and ready to cook. The store also sells fresh, unmarinated but well-trimmed meat, some vegetables and condiments, and prepared dishes like roast chickens ($6 each), pork buns and dumplings, and offers hot prepared dishes at $2.75 a portion. There is also a bakery and sushi counter. Everything is clearly labeled in English as well as in Chinese.
abstract: Many Chinese dishes cook in minutes, but the trimming, chopping, seasoning and marinating you have to do beforehand can take considerable time.

snippet: Penelope Casas reviews restaurants in Valencia region of Spain that serve paella: La Tasca del Puerto, L'Establiment, La Sucursal, Casa Salvador, Nou Manolin and Darsena; photos; map; list (M)
lead_paragraph: PAELLAS, glorious rice creations from the Valencia region of Spain, are among those proverbial dishes that don't travel well. Their secret may be the special chemical composition of Valencia's water, the native rice varieties, or simply the profound know-how of Valencians who have been preparing rice all their lives and eating it just about every day. Whatever the reasons, paellas along the eastern coast of Spain are as good as they get -- unmatched by tepid imitations at most Spanish restaurants in the United States or even in other parts of Spain.

snippet: What's your taste in ice cream? If it runs to classic old-fashioned flavors, then what Mark Thompson makes for the Brooklyn Ice Cream Factory, in a landmark fireboat house on a pier in the shadow of the Brooklyn Bridge, is for you. Chocolate, vani...
lead_paragraph: What's your taste in ice cream? If it runs to classic old-fashioned flavors, then what Mark Thompson makes for the Brooklyn Ice Cream Factory, in a landmark fireboat house on a pier in the shadow of the Brooklyn Bridge, is for you. Chocolate, vanilla, butter pecan, strawberry and a few others ($3 for two scoops) are made without eggs. One innovation is hot caramel sauce, made by Ellen Sternau, pastry chef at the River Café next door. This weekend, Mr. Thompson's ice creams and some sorbets will also be sold from a shed at the end of the pier.

lead_paragraph: NEDERLANDER-Harry Jay. The oldest of five brothers who run a theater empire that stretches from London to Los Angeles, died of cancer January 6, 2002 at his home in Rancho Mirage, California. He was 84. A Detroit native he also has a residence in Bloomfield Hills, MI. He was a Veteran of the US Army Ordinance Corps-WW II. Spearheaded by his father David T. Nederlander a showman and theater operator, Harry and his brothers owned or managed theaters in New York, Chicago, Cincinnati, Los Angeles, San Francisco, Detroit & London. A partner in the New York Yankees he is also on the Board at Beaumont Hospital in Michigan and Federated Investors in Pennsylvania. Lifetime honorary Chairman of the Board and past president of the Bloomfield Open Hunt Club, Bloomfield Hills, MI where he helped organize horse shows for many years. Also a member of the Bloomfield Hills Country Club and Morningside Country Club in Rancho Mirage where he was an avid golfer. He is survived by his wife, Marjorie; their children, Robert Wayne Nederlander, Harry Jay ''Skip'' Nederlander, Jr., Scott E. Nederlander (Dawn), Kathryn Breech Raft (Dr. Arnold) and W. Kimball Breech (Kristin); grandchildren; Taylor, Sarah, Chandra, Erin, Chad, Lauren, & Kristin; brothers, James Nederlander (Charlene), Frederick Nederlander (Betty), Joseph Nederlander (Carole) & Robert Nederlander (Gladys) and one sister Frances Nederlander Kohn. Memorial service Friday in suburban Detroit. No flowers please, family suggests memorials to Wayne State University Apple Award, 5104 Gullen Mass, Detroit, MI 48202 or Michigan Association For Children With Emotional Disorders (MACED), 15920 W. Twelve Mile Rd., Ste 201, Southfield, MI 48076. For information A.J. Desmond & Sons 800-294-5668

lead_paragraph: PARIS—  It was inevitable. In the early days of January, as euro notes and coins made their way into wallets and pocketbooks, Europeans discovered from newspapers and their own travels that a bottle of Evian is 80 percent more expensive in Germany than in France and that a liter of milk costs €1.22 ($1.65) in Italy and just €0.67 in Portugal.

lead_paragraph: Arabica from Tanzania is the cabernet of coffee: a dark, rich brew with an aroma that hints of raisins and is balanced with good acidity. That describes the dark roast coffee from Sweet Unity Farms, a cooperative community in southern Tanzania that was started about 20 years ago by David Robinson, who settled in Tanzania. Mr. Robinson is a son of Jackie Robinson, the baseball player. A 12-ounce bag, caffeinated only, ground or whole bean, is $8 at Garden of Eden in Manhattan and Brooklyn, Jerry's Red Horse Market in East Hampton, N.Y., or from www. sweetunityfarms.com.

snippet: Alan Riding Arts Abroad column reviews British Museum exhibition Queen of Sheba: Treasures from Ancient Yemen; photos (M)
lead_paragraph: The Queen of Sheba probably never existed. Fortunately, as with many great legends, this is merely a detail. Certainly it has not prevented the mysterious lady from southern Arabia from living a full life in religious texts and in the popular imagination for well over 2,000 years. And it has not stood in the way of an exhibition at the British Museum called ''Queen of Sheba: Treasures From Ancient Yemen.''
abstract: Alan Riding Arts Abroad column reviews British Museum exhibition Queen of Sheba: Treasures from Ancient Yemen; photos (M)

snippet: James Schembari Midstream column remarks on change in consumer pride and preference; people used to boast about how much they paid for purchases; now they try to impress by telling how much money they saved; drawing (M)
lead_paragraph: IF we baby boomers have been criticized for anything, it is our tendency to live the high life. If we can afford nice things, we buy them. Why stay at a hotel when a resort is nearby? Why watch television on a little screen? We traded our sedans for sport utility vehicles, then got rid of the first models when the luxury carmakers jumped in. Now BMW, Mercedes and even Porsche, for goodness' sake, are putting such powerful engines into their sport utility vehicles that drivers can have it all -- an S.U.V. that is also a sports car. Did they do that just for us?

lead_paragraph: IN THE FOOTSTEPS OF MR. KURTZ: Living on the Brink of Disaster in Mobutu's Congo, by Michela Wrong. (Perennial/HarperCollins, $13.95.) A foreign correspondent who spent several years in Congo (formerly known as Zaire) recounts the depredations of Mobutu Sese Seko, who during his 32 years as dictator looted the nation of billions while creating ''a parody of a functioning state.'' ''Her firsthand, and first-rate, account'' is filled with ''well-reported anecdotes,'' Ian Fisher wrote in the Book Review last year. ''The details are what give her story its juice.'' In The Graves Are Not Yet Full: Race, Tribe and Power in the Heart of Africa, by Bill Berkeley (Basic Books, $16), another well-traveled journalist argues that the continent's ruinous violence and chaos are fostered by governments that operate like criminal syndicates (the West also deserves much of the blame). Fisher found this ''a smart and broad introduction to the political crisis in Africa.''
abstract: IN THE FOOTSTEPS OF MR. KURTZ: Living on the Brink of Disaster in Mobutu's Congo, by Michela Wrong. (Perennial/HarperCollins, $13.95.) A foreign correspondent who spent several years in Congo (formerly known as Zaire) recounts the depredations of Mobutu Sese Seko, who during his 32 years as dictator looted the nation of billions while creating ''a parody of a functioning state.'' ''Her firsthand, and first-rate, account'' is filled with ''well-reported anecdotes,'' Ian Fisher wrote in the Book Review last year. ''The details are what give her story its juice.'' In The Graves Are Not Yet Full: Race, Tribe and Power in the Heart of Africa, by Bill Berkeley (Basic Books, $16), another well-traveled journalist argues that the continent's ruinous violence and chaos are fostered by governments that operate like criminal syndicates (the West also deserves much of the blame). Fisher found this ''a smart and broad introduction to the political crisis in Africa.''    P.S., by Helen Schulman. (Bloomsbury, $13.95.) Louise Harrington is a divorced 38-year-old woman who gleefully stumbles into a fairy tale when she is reunited with a high-school boyfriend who has died in an accident and been reincarnated as a dashing 24-year-old dreamboat. Last year our reviewer, Bliss Broyard, called this a ''fresh and funny love story'' about a lonely woman who discovers a new version of herself.    THE BOTANY OF DESIRE: A Plant's-Eye View of the World, by Michael Pollan. (Random House, $13.95.) Linking four basic human desires (sweetness, beauty, intoxication and control) with plants that satisfy them (apples, tulips, marijuana and potatoes), the author explores how plant species have thrived over the millenniums by seducing other creatures, including humans. ''Pollan really loves plants,'' Burkhard Bilger said here last year, and ''his prose both shimmers and snaps.'' Two other books reissued in time for gardening season include The Rose's Kiss: A Natural History of Flowers, by Peter Bernhardt (University of Chicago, $16), which in 1999 our reviewer, Verlyn Klinkenborg, called ''an engaging botanical overview of flowers,'' and Anatomy of a Rose: Exploring the Secret Life of Flowers, by Sharman Apt Russell (Perseus, $13). Last year one critic said this ''luminous blend of memoir, botany lesson and history of science'' is ''like a guided walking tour in a field of wildflowers.''    A PERFECT ARRANGEMENT, by Suzanne Berne. (Plume, $13.) In this disturbing tale about the lies, distortions and secrets of a contemporary family, a well-off working couple yield their children to a ''perfect'' nanny who is equally skilled at telling people what they want to hear and at seeing what she wants to see. The result is a ''penetrating, beautifully written novel,'' Elizabeth Graver wrote in these pages in 2001.    THE COLLECTED STORIES OF RICHARD YATES. (Picador USA, $16.) Whether they concern suburban housewives, young soldiers on the prowl in Paris, advertising executives or aspiring Hollywood screenwriters, these tales by the author of ''Revolutionary Road'' focus unflinchingly on lives gone sour and human weakness -- mainly self-deception and the dimly understood yearning for more luck, time and opportunity. Last year in the Book Review, Anthony Quinn called this a ''superb collection'' by ''a laureate of romantic loneliness.''    THE SHAPE OF SNAKES, by Minette Walters. (Jove, $7.99.) Haunted by the violent death of a black woman with Tourette's syndrome 20 years earlier, an English schoolteacher recreates the harrowing event with the help of newspaper clippings, police reports and personal letters, and forces her racist neighbors to confront their role in the murder. In 2001 our reviewer, Marilyn Stasio, praised the novelist's ''commanding control over her inflammatory material -- and her readers.''    MARTHA PEAKE: A Novel of the American Revolution, by Patrick McGrath. (Vintage Contemporaries, $14.95.) This unsettling novel, which unfolds on strikingly different narrative levels, tells of a young man who is summoned by his dying uncle in 19th-century England to hear the story of a hideously deformed smuggler, poet and tormented soul whose daughter emigrated to America and became a martyr of the Revolution. In 2000 our reviewer, Barry Unsworth, found the book uneven but admired its ''rare qualities of power and urgency.''   Scott Veale

Silver Queen, Sweet Magic, White Saturn and Argent are traded across picnic tables and grown all over the state, sometimes eaten in the raw, more often rushed to a boiling pot. lead_paragraph: FOUND Andes by mistake — I drove into the village and felt an immediate affinity with the place," said Tom Munro, a Manhattan fashion photographer who shoots for Vogue and Details. He made a wrong turn that day three years ago, but now he owns a home in Andes, a town in remote Delaware County, N.Y., where unblemished farmland and rolling meadows, juxtaposed against the panoramic backdrop of the Catskill Mountains, create a landscape both pastoral and majestic.

snippet: Melissa Clark comments on tamarind, lemon of Southeast Asia, India and much of Latin America; recipes; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: TAMARIND is the lemon of Southeast Asia, India and much of Latin America; its tart fruitiness sharpens and rounds out flavors wherever it is used. But unlike lemon, which requires nothing more than a squeeze, tamarind does not give up its intense liquid easily. Its bulbous pods are peeled and pressed into a block of pulp that needs to be soaked, mashed and strained. Most tamarind concentrates (or extracts), like bottled lemon juice, are acrid and unpleasant.

lead_paragraph: A Hard Nut to Crack
abstract: A Hard Nut to Crack    Q. We have several large black walnut trees and have had trouble getting anything to grow in their vicinity because of the toxin they emit. Is there any way we can get rid of it short of cutting them down?    A. The toxin, called juglone, cannot be easily neutralized -- and it can persist in the soil for years, so even a chain saw won't help. Juglone is present in all parts of the tree, but is especially strong in the roots, which extend far beyond the canopy.

snippet: Survey paid for by Public Policy Institute of California suggests that it is common for immigrants who have become staple of Silicon Valley's growth to export their experience--and Northern California's entrepreneurial culture--back to their homel...
lead_paragraph: Hong Lu, born in Taiwan, raised in Japan, educated at Berkeley and made wealthy in Silicon Valley, founded a company several years ago to sell telecommunications equipment in mainland China. His intention was to take advantage of his multicultural expertise, aim at a growing market and, incidentally, spread the entrepreneurial culture in Asia.
abstract: Survey paid for by Public Policy Institute of California suggests that it is common for immigrants who have become staple of Silicon Valley's growth to export their experience--and Northern California's entrepreneurial culture--back to their homelands; finds that immigrant entrepreneurs and professionals, in particular from China and India, increasingly are meeting with government officials and consulting with companies in their native countries; finds that 18 percent of immigrants surveyed had invested in their own start-ups or in venture funds in their homelands; survey seeks to illuminate complex labor ties and economic relationship between Silicon Valley and East Asia--relationship that has sometimes been criticized as disproportionately benefiting US; some economists, industry analysts and foreign officials have lamented what they call brain drain from Asian countries--with computer programmers and experts flocking to Silicon Valley for higher pay and better standard of living; University of California at Berkley researcher who conducted study, AnnaLee Saxenian, says data suggests there is 'brain circulation'; Hong Lu, co-founder of UTStarcom, company with its headquarters in Alameda, Calif, and its operations in Beijing, comments; photo (M)

lead_paragraph: Q. What is the difference between 802.11b and 802.11a wireless networking?
abstract: Q. What is the difference between 802.11b and 802.11a wireless networking?    A. The two technologies are part of a group of wireless networking standards that include yet another version, the nascent 802.11g. For a computer user, the differences among the standards mainly involve data transfer speed, the physical distance from the wireless base station (also called an access point) to the wireless-equipped computer, and the radio spectrum frequency on which the standard operates.

lead_paragraph: Andersen Chose Indictment Over an Admission of Guilt
abstract: Andersen Chose Indictment Over an Admission of Guilt  Justice Department officials were willing to consider deferring the prosecution of Arthur Andersen, letting it avoid indictment, if the firm publicly acknowledged that it had illegally destroyed documents in the Enron inquiry and agreed to restrictions similar to probation, according to people involved in the case.    But discussions of such an idea, raised in talks between the government and Andersen several weeks ago, never got off the ground because Andersen believed that such an admission would have been just as devastating as an indictment or guilty plea and also that the firm had not broken any laws. [Page A1.]

lead_paragraph: ''Many people were collapsing around us and dying,'' says a Kurdish man who survived a poison gas attack. ''The gas smelled of garlic and rotten apples.'' As he recalls that day, we see videotape shot immediately after the attack. The gas -- a combination including the nerve gas sarin and cyanide -- caused paralysis and death so fast that the stonelike corpses littering the ground look flash-frozen, fists clenched, one child's arm still lifted in the air.

snippet: David Thomson article on how Eastern European Jews who helped create Hollywood motion picture industry enjoyed Christmas holiday season; focuses on Louis B Mayer, David O Selznick and Darryl F Zanick; photos (M)
lead_paragraph: WHEN you come to a strange land, what must you do if you wish to be master of ceremonies and king at the box office? Co-opt the sentiments and the ritual occasions of the natives. Case in point, Christmas: act as if you've always owned it. Little wonder, then, that as Jewish businessmen slipped from the garment industry into the movies in the early days of Hollywood, they got a handle on Christmas.

snippet: Article on 36-hour visit to Stowe, Vt; photos; maps (M)
lead_paragraph: TUCKED into the northern edge of the Green Mountains in Vermont, Stowe is an authentic ski town steadfastly retaining its New England charm while conceding to the commercial development that a landscape of such raw beauty inevitably generates. Mount Mansfield, the state's highest peak, looms over the 230-year-old town, while the West Branch River slices through it, passing an inn, a general store and the quintessential Vermont white-steepled church. The heart of town is the intersection of Route 100, which runs along the spine of the Green Mountains, and Route 108, also known as Mountain Road, which closes in winter just beyond the Stowe Mountain Resort. Many of the village's lodgings, retail shops, restaurants and watering holes are clustered along the eight-mile stretch of Mountain Road between the village and the ski area, called simply ''the hill'' by locals. Stowe's population (just over 4,000 in 2000) has grown only tenfold in 200 years, but the seasonal influx of second-home owners and visitors increases the number of vehicles in town disproportionately. The traffic along Mountain Road can get nasty, especially during the height of winter, so time your outings wisely. If your visit coincides with the Stowe Winter Carnival (Jan. 17 to 26), be sure to take part in one of the many zany events around town, like moonlight turkey bowling on the frozen pond behind the Commodores Inn (www.stowewintercarnival). WENDY KNIGHT

lead_paragraph: Demonology: Stories , by Rick Moody. (Back Bay/Little, Brown, $13.95.) Many of the youngish males who dominate these rambunctious and risky tales have grad-school minds but ninth-grade hearts, and they keep losing their grip as they scramble for a foothold on life's ladder. ''Moody has spirit and drive and talent to burn,'' Walter Kirn wrote in the Book Review last year. ''He's working a challenging, fascinating angle in his best stories -- assessing and enacting the ways that language can by turns overcome and be overcome by loss.''
