lead_paragraph: DEMONOLOGY: Stories, by Rick Moody. (Back Bay/Little, Brown, $13.95.) Many of the youngish males who dominate these rambunctious and risky tales have grad-school minds but ninth-grade hearts, and they keep losing their grip as they scramble for a foothold on life's ladder. ''Moody has spirit and drive and talent to burn,'' Walter Kirn wrote in the Book Review last year. ''He's working a challenging, fascinating angle in his best stories -- assessing and enacting the ways that language can by turns overcome and be overcome by loss.''
abstract: DEMONOLOGY: Stories, by Rick Moody. (Back Bay/Little, Brown, $13.95.) Many of the youngish males who dominate these rambunctious and risky tales have grad-school minds but ninth-grade hearts, and they keep losing their grip as they scramble for a foothold on life's ladder. ''Moody has spirit and drive and talent to burn,'' Walter Kirn wrote in the Book Review last year. ''He's working a challenging, fascinating angle in his best stories -- assessing and enacting the ways that language can by turns overcome and be overcome by loss.''    BODY TOXIC: An Environmental Memoir, by Susanne Antonetta. (Counterpoint, $15.) A poet tells of growing up in southern New Jersey in a landscape blighted by toxic substances and radioactive waste, and of the profound effect her exposure to these poisons had on her health as an adult. For her, chemistry more than childhood trauma shaped her sense of self. ''Antonetta's considerable achievement . . . is to devise a literary voice for people who live in such places,'' Michael Pollan said here in 2001.    SIMPLE STORIES, by Ingo Schulze. (Vintage International, $13.) This German author's first novel is a baroquely expansive pastiche that employs 12 narrators from three generations to describe how a bunch of stodgy, provincial East Germans are forced to reinvent themselves after the fall of the Berlin Wall. ''It's a brilliant narrative strategy for capturing a time of giddy terror and -- much more rarely -- exhilaration,'' Suzanne Ruta wrote here in 2000.    BEFORE THE STORM: Barry Goldwater and the Unmaking of the American Consensus, by Rick Perlstein. (Hill & Wang, $17.) A scholar traces the origins of today's conservative movement to the Goldwater years and the Republican Party's resounding defeat in the 1964 presidential election. The result is ''a detailed and dramatic narrative of the rise of the modern right'' that combines ''prodigious research with journalistic flair,'' William Kristol wrote here in 2001.    THE END OF DAYS: Fundamentalism and the Struggle for the Temple Mount, by Gershom Gorenberg. (Oxford University, $15.95.) A senior editor and columnist for The Jerusalem Post examines the incendiary mix of religious groups -- Arab, Jewish and fundamentalist Christians -- that view the destiny of the sacred Temple Mount as crucial to their apocalyptic faith. In his interviews with a broad spectrum of true believers, the author ''shows himself an insightful listener,'' John Dorfman said here last year.    ULTIMATE JOURNEY: Retracing the Path of an Ancient Buddhist Monk Who Crossed Asia in Search of Enlightenment, by Richard Bernstein. (Vintage Departures, $14.) The author, a book critic for The New York Times, follows the footsteps of Hsuan Tsang, a seventh-century Chinese monk whose odyssey spanned 10,000 miles and 17 years. Last year our reviewer, Alexander Frater, called this an ''intricate, closely argued and beautifully observed'' traveler's tale ''by a man . . . driven as much by the quiet despair of middle age as by a search for deeper meaning.''    COMFORT ME WITH APPLES: More Adventures at the Table, by Ruth Reichl. (Random House, $13.95.) In the sequel to her 1998 memoir, ''Tender at the Bone,'' the author picks up her story with her entry into the restaurant-critic business (now editor in chief of Gourmet, she is also a former critic for The Times), and in recounting her culinary and personal experiences she is always keenly aware of the way life is shaped by work, money and, yes, eating. ''Reichl understands that food lies at the center of human sociality,'' Paul Mattick wrote here last year. ''At the heart of her book is love (however laced with conflict) for her friends and family, and her wish to extend their number by having a child.''    DEATH OF A RIVER GUIDE, by Richard Flanagan. (Grove, $13.) As the narrator of this first novel slowly drowns after rescuing a tourist during a raft trip in the Tasmanian wild, his thoughts swirl around his own sad, unhappy life, his family's ancestral secrets and the lurid, striking history of Tasmania itself. The result is a ''haunting and ambitious'' tale, Jennifer Reese said here in 2001.    AFFINITY, by Sarah Waters. (Riverhead, $14.) The alternating journal entries of an upper-class Victorian lady doing charity work at an English prison and a female spiritualist convicted of fraud and assault reveals a growing -- and seemingly magical -- connection between the women. In 2000 our reviewer, Nancy Willard, called this novel ''a wrenching love story.''   Scott Veale

lead_paragraph: ONE unusual feature of Runyon Heights is the large number of dead-end streets. Situated on 110 hilly acres in the northeast corner of Yonkers, New York's fourth largest, the suburban neighborhood, the former estate of Charles Runyon, a New York City industrialist, was designed in the years before World War I with few through streets -- a geographic entity unto itself and separate from the other neighborhoods in what was then a predominantly white metropolis.
abstract: ONE unusual feature of Runyon Heights is the large number of dead-end streets. Situated on 110 hilly acres in the northeast corner of Yonkers, New York's fourth largest, the suburban neighborhood, the former estate of Charles Runyon, a New York City industrialist, was designed in the years before World War I with few through streets -- a geographic entity unto itself and separate from the other neighborhoods in what was then a predominantly white metropolis.    In Yonkers, which was riven by racial tensions for much of the 20th century, Runyon Heights was, according to residents and a scholar's recent book about the neighborhood, the only area that welcomed black home buyers. (The largely minority southwest section of the city is mostly low-rent tenements and public housing.) About 17 miles from Midtown Manhattan, Runyon Heights also became one of the first predominantly black suburban areas in the metropolitan region, drawing residents north from Harlem.

snippet: Dr Kent A Sepkowitz article says experts from around world attending 14th International AIDS conference in Barcelona will probably discuss latest advances, and focus on developing scientific strategy for vaccine development; says they will probabl...
lead_paragraph: AT the 14th International AIDS conference, which opens today in Barcelona, the tone can be expected to be both optimistic (new drugs on the horizon) and bleak (the global epidemic). For the next six days, experts from around the world will discuss the latest advances in controlling AIDS, which now causes 14,000 new infections daily -- about 10 per minute. Scores of presentations will feature the still unproved AIDS vaccine, which is seen as the only chance to contain this epidemic.
abstract: Dr Kent A Sepkowitz article says experts from around world attending 14th International AIDS conference in Barcelona will probably discuss latest advances, and focus on developing scientific strategy for vaccine development; says they will probably pay scant attention to simple and widely acknowledged approach to control spread of HIV: the condom; notes that for variety of cultural reasons, condoms in many ways remain in shadows, even in America; photo (M)

snippet: Enron's collapse is expected to raise the heat at corporate annual meetings this year, with anxious shareholders probing details of balance sheets and putting hard questions to executives and directors; chief executives can also expect to be asked...
lead_paragraph: CORPORATE annual meetings used to be sedate affairs, smoothly choreographed by management, some lasting a mere 15 minutes. Sometimes, a handful of institutional investors or a few curmudgeonly shareholder gadflies forced the board to focus on corporate governance issues, but management usually was able to brush aside their concerns. Many small investors, meanwhile, were unclear about why corporate governance even mattered.
abstract: Enron's collapse is expected to raise the heat at corporate annual meetings this year, with anxious shareholders probing details of balance sheets and putting hard questions to executives and directors; chief executives can also expect to be asked about their compensation systems, which some investors believe have been distorted from their original purpose; drawing (M)

snippet: Margaret Talbot essay says what teenagers are taught about sex these days makes it seem like dangerous, dirty business; says Judith Levine, author of book on sex education, claims this is result of increasing influence in sex education of abstinen...
lead_paragraph: I've always been fond of the movie ''A Summer Place,'' one of those late-50's Technicolor melodramas that can barely contain the enormous and genuine emotions it evokes. Its subject is the dangers for teenagers of sexual repression, and the dangers for their parents of lying to them about it -- quite a radical subject when you think about it, though sometimes it's hard to with the made-for-Muzak theme song swelling on the soundtrack. Molly, played by the 17-year-old Sandra Dee, of the cotton-candy hair and the candy-apple lips, willingly goes all the way with lanky, sensitive Johnny, played by Troy Donahue, of course.
abstract: Margaret Talbot essay says what teenagers are taught about sex these days makes it seem like dangerous, dirty business; says Judith Levine, author of book on sex education, claims this is result of increasing influence in sex education of abstinence-only ideology; holds that one cliche about sex education is that it should not send 'mixed messages'; says better approach is abstinence-plus education, in which teenagers are discouraged from rushing into sex but also given information about contraception; photos (M)

snippet: Jon Pareles reviews concert by Paul McCartney at Continental Airlines Arena; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: Paul McCartney wore his illustrious past lightly when he performed tonight at the Continental Airlines Arena here. Genially and almost casually, he played more than 30 songs in a two-and-a-half-hour set. Nearly all of them -- rockers and ballads, gems and duds -- are etched into the memories of a generation, and Sir Paul aimed to stir those memories gently and thoroughly. Video clips showed him in his younger days with the Beatles and Wings, and when he sang ''I Saw Her Standing There,'' the live video switched to black-and-white, the way many fans first saw him sing it.
abstract: Jon Pareles reviews concert by Paul McCartney at Continental Airlines Arena; photo (M)

snippet: Jonathan Reynolds column on foraging for and cooking with wild mushrooms; recipes; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: ''Hello -- now go away, I have work to do,'' said Philip Hanes, my host for the weekend at the splendid lodge he shares with a dozen or so partners in western North Carolina. He was shaving slices from a basketball-size hen of the woods mushroom. Such a greeting might drive ordinary folk out the door and relegate Philip to honorary curmudgeon status, but for those of us who know this 76-year-old and the apple-cheeked smile that makes you see the 12-year-old in him and his brain that whirs like a weathervane in a never-ending hurricane, it's like hugs and kisses. I dutifully headed to the wagon-wheel chandeliers and comfy chairs in the log-lined living room, where various weights and depths of cocktail were being served.
abstract: Jonathan Reynolds column on foraging for and cooking with wild mushrooms; recipes; photo (M)

snippet: The Chocolate Room at City Bakery, 3 West 18th Street, is smaller than a walk-in closet but more richly stocked than a rack of Chanels.
lead_paragraph: The Chocolate Room at City Bakery, 3 West 18th Street, is smaller than a walk-in closet but more richly stocked than a rack of Chanels. For Valentine's Day, its shelves are laden with dark chocolate fudge so intense and smooth it's almost like ganache ($10 for about one pound). It is best refrigerated until almost-indulging time. Cocoa-dusted chocolate truffles ($20 for a half pound), chocolate chip cookies ($6 for three) and biscotti ($5 for 6 to 8) are other ready-to-eat items. For bakers, there are City Bakery's own chocolate and chocolate chips.
abstract: The Chocolate Room at City Bakery, 3 West 18th Street, is smaller than a walk-in closet but more richly stocked than a rack of Chanels.

With all of our love, Amy and Ronnie Goldberger    SCHIFF-Stuart. I wish to express my sincere condolences to the entire family of Stuart Schiff. He was a legend in our business and I am grateful for having the pleasure of dealing with him for 20+ years of my career. I felt privileged to have served with him on REBNY's Grand Central Committee where I had seen him as recently as last Tuesday at the monthly meeting. My heart aches for his family. May his memory be a blessing. Billy Cohen    SCHIFF-Stuart. Stu was a fixture of the real estate industry for over twentyfive years and was respected by all. He will be sorely missed.    SCHIFF-Stuart. snippet: Anita Gates previews some of week's top movies on television; photo (S)
lead_paragraph: IF you're expecting deep, thought-provoking cinema from Lasse Hallstrom's CHOCOLAT (2000), you'll be disappointed. But if you're in the mood for a light indulgence and don't mind being manipulated into one of the least shocking messages of our time (that sensuality is good and repression is bad), this is the film for you. Juliette Binoche stars as a single mother who moves to a tranquil French village, opens a chocolate shop there and transforms everyone. Alfred Molina is the stern and disapproving mayor, who ends up enjoying a personal orgy of chocoholism. Judi Dench is a cranky old lady rejuvenated by hot chocolate and memories. Lena Olin is a mousy villager who discovers a new aphrodisiac. Johnny Depp is the handsome Gypsy who comes to town - Tuesday at 2 and 10:20 p.m. on Starz.

lead_paragraph: DOUBLE FOLD: Libraries and the Assault on Paper, by Nicholson Baker. (Vintage, $14.) It may seem like an odd subject for this radically original fiction writer to pursue, but in full obsessive-compulsive froth he issues a jeremiad against the nation's libraries (including the Library of Congress), which are jettisoning books and newspapers and replacing them with microfilm copies. His plea for preservation ''got me, as he intended, hopping mad,'' David Gates wrote here last year. ''If there's justice in the world, he'll rattle some cages.''
abstract: DOUBLE FOLD: Libraries and the Assault on Paper, by Nicholson Baker. (Vintage, $14.) It may seem like an odd subject for this radically original fiction writer to pursue, but in full obsessive-compulsive froth he issues a jeremiad against the nation's libraries (including the Library of Congress), which are jettisoning books and newspapers and replacing them with microfilm copies. His plea for preservation ''got me, as he intended, hopping mad,'' David Gates wrote here last year. ''If there's justice in the world, he'll rattle some cages.''    THREE APPLES FELL FROM HEAVEN, by Micheline Aharonian Marcom. (Riverhead, $14.) This darkly vivid first novel depicts the suffering of Christian Armenians at the hands of the Ottoman Empire during World War I, but includes moments of tenderness, courage and unexpected generosity. ''The fierce beauty'' of the prose ''confronts readers with many breathtaking cruelties and carries us past them,'' Margot Livesey wrote here in 2001.    DRAGON HUNTER: Roy Chapman Andrews and the Central Asiatic Expeditions, by Charles Gallenkamp. (Penguin, $15.) Andrews was a world-famous explorer-zoologist, a real-life Indiana Jones whose hair-raising adventures culminated in five expeditions into Mongolia between 1922 and 1930 and the discovery of an amazing trove of dinosaur remains. Last year our reviewer, Barry Gewen, called this an ''enormously entertaining'' biography.    THE HOUSE IN PARIS, by Elizabeth Bowen. (Anchor, $13.) This 1936 novel takes place at a prim boardinghouse in Paris, where a doomed love affair has tragic consequences that resurface years later with the arrival of a mysterious young boy who has come to meet a mother he has never seen. Our reviewer, Edith H. Walton, admired the ''magic nicety'' of Bowen's style and said the tale ''is so perfect of its kind, so witty and so subtly exciting, that even those with robuster tastes can hardly deny its excellence.''    THE MORNING AFTER . . . and Long After: Selected Essays and Reviews, by Wilfrid Sheed. (Akadine, $19.95.) This 1971 collection of literary criticism and other nonfiction has been updated with a new introduction, a recent review and a 1999 essay about Sheed's experiences on the editorial board of the Book-of-the-Month Club. The book is ''dazzling, hilarious, astringent, serious without pomposity,'' Thomas R. Edwards wrote in these pages. The same publisher has restored to print Sheed's novel Max Jamison ($18.95), which explores the plight of a successful but burned-out theater critic groaning under the weight of his personal and professional obligations. In 1970 our reviewer, Richard Rhodes, found this book ''as interesting as . . . a clinical case study.'' Akadine has also reissued In Love With Daylight: A Memoir of Recovery ($16.95), Sheed's grim but buoyantly told 1995 account of his battles with alcohol, prescription drugs and metastatic cancer of the tongue.    POEMS: 1968-1998, by Paul Muldoon. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $19.) This collection features 30 years of protean verse by the dazzling and elusive Northern Irish poet (at right). Last year our reviewer, Richard Eder, admired Muldoon's ''whiplash of association and disassociation'' while noting that he ''has written poems of poignant directness as well.'' The same publisher has reissued ElectRic Light, by Seamus Heaney ($13), like Muldoon a Roman Catholic from Northern Ireland, whose latest book is a rich compendium of genres, from elegy to ecstatic lyric. It is the mature work of a master poet aware both of his aging and of his cultural authority and the responsibilities that go with it. The collection reflects ''Heaney's will (and ability) to speak of many kinds of experience to many kinds of reader,'' Langdon Hammer wrote in the Book Review in 2001.    KOSOVO CROSSING: The Reality of American Intervention in the Balkans, by David Fromkin. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $12.) The author examines Kosovo as a ''prism'' through which to study the extent to which America is willing and able to do good in the world. Fromkin ''brings to his subject both learning and a delightful prose style,'' Michael Elliott said here in 1999. Stay the Hand of Vengeance: The Politics of War Crimes Tribunals, by Gary Jonathan Bass (Princeton University, $19.95), is an exhaustive survey of how political leaders have dealt with the problem of war criminals since 1815 -- it's a mixed record, at best. Bass ''argues convincingly that trying war criminals is a better option than its alternative: vengeance,'' Chuck Sudetic wrote here in 2000.   Scott Veale

snippet: William Grimes reviews Black Duck, American seafood restaurant; photo (Diner's Journal) (M)
lead_paragraph: The Black Duck, on the ground floor of a renovated 18th-century Federal-style town house, makes a dignified presence on a raffish stretch of 28th Street. Surrounded by all-night produce stores, cheap ethnic restaurants and a parking lot across the street, it somehow manages to give the impression that it sits right in the middle of Georgetown. The clubby interior, with dark-wood wainscoting and nautical paintings, and the American seafood menu, put it in the scallop, scrod and pewter school of American restaurants. It's a style encountered all up and down the Atlantic coast, but not all that often in Manhattan. The owners, Atlantic Stars Hospitality Group, are a hotel and cruise-ship company based in Newport, R.I., so the nautical theme is second nature.

snippet: William Grimes reviews Moda, Italian restaurant in Flatotel on West 52nd Street; photo (M)s
lead_paragraph: THE first surprise at Moda comes at the start of the meal. A waiter drops by and puts a small plate on the table. It has a lot going on in a small area. There is an assortment of very good olives, a few pickled lupini beans and heaped chunks of Parmesan, one of the few cheeses that's equally good grated or whole. Among the tidbits is a small dish filled with good olive oil and another with an irresistible blend of butter and olive oil sprinkled with crunchy grains of salt. There's a lot to be said for keeping diners busy as they study the menu.

lead_paragraph: DEAR DIARY:
abstract: DEAR DIARY:    A friend, another lifelong New Yorker, just returned from getting her M.B.A. at Dartmouth. Before she left New Hampshire, a car knocked the side mirror of her car loose, leaving it dangling by a single wire. For the drive back to New York, she rigged it back into place with a couple of heavy rubber bands. When she arrived here, she parked just outside her apartment at Union Square.    The next morning she went out, and when she started to tell me what happened, I could tell by her tone that there would be a dramatic ending. ''Someone took your mirror,'' I said, knowingly.

snippet: Northern Italy produces great regional delicacy called frico del fattore, cheese melted in pan, then cooled, cracked into shards and served as accompaniment; history of dish discussed; recipe; photos (M)
lead_paragraph: IT is a simple dish for a complicated part of the world. Frico, they call it: cheese melted in a pan, then allowed to cool into a sheet that cracks into shards under a finger's pressure. Served as the farmers eat it, with potatoes, onions, a bit of smoky bacon, it is called frico del fattore, and it rates as one of the great regional delicacies of a nation that is filled with them. To find it -- and the Montasio cheese with which it is made -- I set out one warm, cloudless morning to drive from the high plains of this central city in Italy's northeastern corner up into the Dolomites, to the tiny village of Sauris di Sotto.
abstract: Northern Italy produces great regional delicacy called frico del fattore, cheese melted in pan, then cooled, cracked into shards and served as accompaniment; history of dish discussed; recipe; photos (M)

The boy, Paul Muldoon, had just been introduced to Mr. Heaney, the poet, by his high school English teacher at a reading in Armagh in Northern Ireland. Mr. Muldoon asked if he could send Mr. Heaney his poems. He said yes, and in the mail they came.

lead_paragraph: Richard A. Gephardt, the House Democratic leader who has been putting a new emphasis on cleaning up corporate America, celebrated 25 years in Congress on Thursday with a $500,000 fund-raising reception at a downtown hotel. snippet: William Grimes reviews Marseille, Moroccan-accented Mediterranean restaurant on Ninth Avenue and 44th Street; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: THE Marseille hovering behind Marseille the restaurant is not a real city. It is a poetic notion, a constellation of tastes, a vision of fierce white sunlight, bright blue water and chilled pink wine. It is, in short, a license to invent, and Alex Ureña, Marseille's executive chef, has taken full advantage in this spacious, confident-feeling brasserie on the western edge of the theater district. He has not committed the sacrilege of leaving bouillabaisse off the menu, but, like his wine list, he wanders at will all over the Mediterranean, gathering ingredients from North Africa, Spain, Italy and France.

lead_paragraph: ASK most people if they've heard of the Northern Neck of Virginia and you will probably have to mention famous Williamsburg, an hour south, to help them get their bearings. The state's northernmost peninsula, jutting out to the widest part of Chesapeake Bay, flanked by the Potomac and Rappahannock Rivers, is home to old fishing villages, former steamboat ports and a wooded waterfront that has resisted large-scale development in a way few American shore towns have. It's every bit as bucolic as Maryland's Eastern Shore.

snippet: Journeys article on 36-hour visit to Burlington, Vt; photos; maps (M)
lead_paragraph: A HIP, outdoorsy city in the northwestern corner of Vermont, Burlington is perhaps best known for its peace-loving, hippie roots. Representative Bernie Sanders, the independent who is Vermont's only representative in the House, was once the socialist mayor of the city. Ben & Jerry's, where corporate activism was dished out along with premium ice cream (at least before it was sold to a conglomerate), opened its first scoop shop at the corner of College and Battery Streets in 1978. Though the enduring activism can turn self-righteous at times, Burlington does manage to show its irreverence -- and tolerance for cold weather -- when it holds a parade and festival each winter at Mardi Gras. Perched on the eastern shore of Lake Champlain, the sixth-largest lake in the United States, and sandwiched between the Adirondacks of New York and the Green Mountains of Vermont, the Burlington area offers plenty of outdoor activities, from flat-water kayaking to stellar hiking. Funky shops, coffee houses and collegiate energy pervade the area, which is the home of the University of Vermont. WENDY KNIGHT
abstract: Journeys article on 36-hour visit to Burlington, Vt; photos; maps (M)

lead_paragraph: Here in southern New England the corn is already waist high and growing so avidly you can almost hear the creak of stalk and leaf as the plants stretch toward the sun. The ears of sweet corn are just starting to show up on local farm stands, inaugurating one of the ceremonies of an American summer. These days the nation's nearly 80 million-acre field of corn rolls across the countryside like a second great lawn, but this wholesome, all-American image obscures a decidedly more dubious reality.
abstract: Michael Pollan Op-Ed article on appearance of first ears of corn, which inaugurate one of ceremonies of American summer, but also represent more dubious reality of massive subsidies that are, in fact, form of 'welfare' for plant that evolved with humans over 10,000 years; explains that corn has triumphed by making itself indispensable not to farmers but to huge companies like Archer Daniels Midland and Coca-Cola that have insinuated corn invisibly into American diets (M)

She broke away, creating her own songs, and they didn't sound much like anyone else's.

snippet: Article by Ann Patchett on taboo about marrying first cousins that is strong is some parts of world and does not exist in other parts of world; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: Thanks to 12 years of Catholic single-sex education, a lack of brothers and an overdeveloped interest in reading as a child, I grew up in a world almost completely devoid of boys. Except, of course, for those boys I was related to. I had 25 first cousins, and I remember many summer family reunions eating sand-infused slices of sheet cake on the beaches of Southern California, so lost in the cousin crush of the moment that I could hardly swallow. These feelings were for the most part unexpressed and interchangeable (I liked cousin Lenny as much as his brother Greg). One crush, however, started when I was 8 and proved hearty enough to follow me into adulthood. Whenever this cousin and I were on the same side of the country there were dinners, hand-holding and a certain amount of sighing. Alas, we would be perfect for each other if only we weren't cousins. But we were, and so, feeling genetically star-crossed, we always said good night and went our separate ways.
abstract: Article by Ann Patchett on taboo about marrying first cousins that is strong is some parts of world and does not exist in other parts of world; photo (M)

Even as the Patriots began their playoff run tonight, everyone wondered what tomorrow would hold for Bledsoe.

snippet: Staggering rush of corporate scandals featuring executives betraying marketplace for own short-term self-interest raises question of whether capitalism can survive capitalist misdeeds; scandals all involve companies lying about their performance, ...
lead_paragraph: OVER the last few centuries, capitalism has been the heartiest contender in the global bout for economic supremacy. It emerged from its decades-long death match with communism as the unquestioned victor. Its dust-up with socialism barely lasted a few rounds. It flourished in wartime, and survived wrongheaded assaults from embargoes and tariffs. Even terrorism aimed at capitalism's heart failed to deliver a knock-out punch.
abstract: Staggering rush of corporate scandals featuring executives betraying marketplace for own short-term self-interest raises question of whether capitalism can survive capitalist misdeeds; scandals all involve companies lying about their performance, and investors paying price; challenge credibility of financial reporting system and investor faith in capital markets that are engine of capitalism's success; photo (M)

lead_paragraph: IF the East End of Long Island conjures up images of hellish traffic, snobbish socialites and publicists behaving badly, you may be ready to discover Southold, on the North Fork. In the middle of Long Island's wine country and framed by the Great Peconic Bay and Long Island Sound, Southold has dazzling waterfront homes and acres of beaches -- but without the conspicuous consumption and bumper-to-bumper bottlenecks. It's a good spot for people who want a low-key, family-centered weekend community.

lead_paragraph: IT was lunch hour, but Suzanne Sideris, an accountant from Malverne, was interested in a youth elixir, not a salad. Instead of a restaurant, Ms. Sideris, 37, sat on the examining table in Dr. Lyle S. Leipziger's Great Neck office and lifted her brow. Like lines on a sheet of loose-leaf paper, fine wrinkles crossed her forehead. She scrunched her eyebrows together. Vertical crevices rippled between them.

snippet: Footnotes references on lowriding customized cars; photos (special section, Men's Fashions of The Times) (part 2 of 2-part section)
lead_paragraph: 1. Lowriders are built for looks, not performance -- at least not in the traditional sense. ''Speed has nothing to do with it,'' observes Dan Stoner, the editor of Garage (a), a style-oriented custom-car quarterly. ''It's all about style and how high you can get the car to hop.'' For some, it's also about the girls. ''It's like a rock band,'' says Anthony Johnson (b), an aficionado from Riverside, Calif., who calls himself Tee. snippet: D T Max column on surprise success of 24-hour-a-day Weather Channel; holds we watch channel for reassurance about state of planet; notes Americans increasingly consume meteorological information as they have less need to go outside; notes people a...
lead_paragraph: The day the Weather Channel went on the air, nearly 20 years ago, it was balmy out, clouds scudding in a high sky, no possibility of rain. Today, looking out my window, I see that is still the case. The weather's still nice. At least there's a breeze. The Weather Channel anchor is right now warning me the weather may change. A front is somewhere not too far away. They say there are five stories in Hollywood. With the weather, there has always been only one. It will get cold, and then it will get warm. Warm, cold, warm, cold.

snippet: With his passion for the past, the fashion guru Cameron Silver brings out the luster in a neglected Modernist gem.
lead_paragraph: With its glass walls that double as doors, split-levels and relentless cool yet surprising coziness, this house in the serene foothills of the Los Feliz section of Los Angeles is a shrine to the promise of Southern California. Cross-ventilated breezes drift through the aerie -- built long before feng shui became a twinkle in the eye of every trendy type this side of Fred Segal -- bringing with it monarch butterflies and birds. By comparison, the buttoned-up mansions of Beverly Hills seem woefully sad, if not cynical.

snippet: William Grimes reports on revival of restaurant scene in New Orleans; reports on some new restaurants he visited; photos (L)
lead_paragraph: The impossible happened in New Orleans a few years ago. The dining scene turned dull. The city that most Americans routinely rank with New York and San Francisco among their favorite food towns seemed to lose the spark. The big Cajun boom of the 1980's, the era of Paul Prudhomme and blackened redfish, was long over, although the tourists still line up at K Paul's. Emeril Lagasse had gone on to become the country's premier celebrity chef, although the tourists still make a beeline for Emeril's, too. The stately old restaurants like Commander's Palace and Galatoire's sailed on, like the great Mississippi riverboats of yore. And you could always go to places like Uglesich's or Mandina's for a taste of something local and authentic. But there was no getting around it, New Orleans was in a slump.
abstract: William Grimes reports on revival of restaurant scene in New Orleans; reports on some new restaurants he visited; photos (L)

snippet: Joanne Starkey reviews 95 School Street restaurant in Bridgehampton, Long Island; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: THE Hamptons in February? Are you kidding? No way. Hold on. Not every East End restaurant is hibernating, and one of them, 95 School Street in Bridgehampton, may be the sleeper of the 2002 season. This nearly decade-old spot, often taken for granted, has been given a shot of adrenaline by a creative new chef. Open seven days a week, even in the dead of winter, 95 School Street is rewarding foodies-in-the-know with a preview of what summer will hold.

lead_paragraph: ONLY 9,000 people live in this charming market town near the Welsh border, surrounded by lush and rolling hills. Just 9,000, but Ludlow has no fewer than three Michelin-starred restaurants -- the greatest concentration anywhere in Britain outside London.
abstract: ONLY 9,000 people live in this charming market town near the Welsh border, surrounded by lush and rolling hills. Just 9,000, but Ludlow has no fewer than three Michelin-starred restaurants -- the greatest concentration anywhere in Britain outside London.    Seats in these celebrated but tiny establishments -- the Merchant House, Hibiscus and Mr. Underhill's at Dinham Weir -- are hard to come by. Together, they have only 21 tables, and their fame is growing. Culinary tourists from Birmingham and Oxford think nothing of spending hours in the car to make a 7 p.m. reservation during the week. And those from London, 140 miles away, are descending on the village in increasing numbers every weekend. Not to eat in just one of the places, but in all of them, over two days: two dinners and lunch, say. (I did it at a more leisurely pace, in three days.)

snippet: Joy Horowitz Journeys article on places to stay and dine, sights to see and things to do on 36-hour trip to Santa Barbara, Calif; map; photos (M)
lead_paragraph: AN old Spanish mission town sandwiched between the Santa Ynez Mountains and the Pacific, Santa Barbara has climbed up hillsides and spilled out along the coast. Expensive neighborhoods and lavish estates rise in gentle terraces (with Ronald Reagan's old ranch somewhere in the higher elevations), looking down on the coastline, the city center and one another. Thanks to plentiful sunshine, celebrity residents (Oprah Winfrey, John Travolta and Brad Pitt all own houses here) and local building codes ensuring red-tiled roofs, Santa Barbara is sometimes called the American Riviera. But don't let the celebrity factor throw you. Upscale restaurants and trendy galleries abound, but so do funky taco stands, affordable antiques shops and lovely stretches of uncrowded, sandy beaches. Just ignore the oil rigs looming, Darth Vader-like, offshore. JOY HOROWITZ

lead_paragraph: DEAR DIARY:
abstract: DEAR DIARY:    Sometimes the best thing about New Yorkers is their fabled provincialism. I recently took a cab from La Guardia Airport to Manhattan, where I was going to spend the weekend. The driver, after I directed him, asked if I was from Boston. No, I said, I had come from Pittsburgh. Then I added: ''But I'm really a New Yorker. I grew up in Brooklyn.''    The driver turned around to look at me. ''Brooklyn?'' he said. ''You grew up in Brooklyn? So what's a nice girl from Brooklyn doing in Pittsburgh?'' It's been three decades since I even remotely resembled a girl, but I let that pass. ''Well, I met a guy and I've been following him ever since,'' I said.

lead_paragraph: Hiking purists might disagree, but New York at night, very late at night, is a great setting for a long walk at a fast pace. In summer the heaviness of the daytime air can weigh down the bounce in anyone's step. But at night an unexpected breeze can inspire walkers to tread again on city sidewalks. Best traversed after midnight when they're mostly quiet, the streets become a wide open, well-lighted trail system, unfolding an urban version of awesome beauty.

lead_paragraph: Can quality of design improve the quality of life? Can it change society? The Swedes take the radical proposition that good modern design can help cure society's ills. This aesthetic philosophy was probably first promoted in Sweden by the socialist reformer Ellen Key (1849-1926), who was profoundly influenced by the English reformers John Ruskin and William Morris. Like them, she felt mass production was hurting aesthetic quality.

But they were surprised when more than 100 Russian singers and teachers and two octets, one from the Georgian Republic, showed up for a series of master classes that the Long Islanders and their colleagues from Manhattan, the Big Apple Chorus, gave last summer in St. Petersburg at the Third Annual St. Petersburg Barbershop Harmony Festival.

snippet: Food column offers recipes for dishes with corn; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: Tom Falkowski's vegetable stand in the Bridgehampton hinterland, opposite the horse farms on Scuttlehole Road, sits atop a ridge that marks the southernmost advance of the great glacier that covered much of the North American continent until the wall of ice made its slow retreat as world temperatures rose some 20,000 years ago. This gentle ridge, called by geologists a terminal moraine, lifts Scuttlehole Road above the rich farmland that slopes southward to the sea. Part of a 100-mile spine marking the glacier's terminal extension, the ridge runs from Brooklyn to Amagansett at the far end of Long Island's South Fork and enters the sea where it may once have formed a third fork, long since eroded. This glacier, aided in its progress by the broad river valley that would later become Long Island Sound, shaped the hundred-mile sandbar known as Long Island.
abstract: Food column offers recipes for dishes with corn; photo (M)

snippet: Julia Reed column on preparing dishes that win praise but are not complicated; recipes; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: I have three cookbooks written in the 50's and 60's whose titles all but declare that cooking and entertaining are about seduction, or at least about showing off: ''The Perfect Hostess Cookbook,'' ''Come for Cocktails, Stay for Supper'' (by Lois Levine and this newspaper's Marian Burros) and my favorite, ''Cooking for Compliments.'' The author of the last one, a radio personality named Martha Deane, gets right to the point. ''We may as well admit that it's fun to be complimented,'' she writes in her preface. ''Possibly sterner generations took a dim view of this thought, fearing that it smacked of the sin of vanity. But modern psychiatrists tell us that happy is she who reaps satisfaction from the work she does. Including her cooking -- of which she will average some 50,000 hours of her married life!''

snippet: Lyle Rexer reviews fairy tale-inspired photographs by Simen Johan at Yosi Milo Gallery and installations by artist Kiki Smith at Pace Wildenstein Gallery; photos (M)
lead_paragraph: IT reaches from the blood-drenched graves of antiquity to the pious legends of a child's picture book. . . . To me it represents all poetry, and he who masters it must be able to put into it tragedy, comedy, naïve simplicity and humor.'' So wrote Hans Christian Andersen of the literary form he practiced, the fairy tale. Fairy tales have cast a spell not only on writers but, just as powerfully, on visual artists. Today, in the spirit of Andersen, artists are telling new tales and revising old ones, creating make-believe landscapes that are definitely not just for children. In them, Little Red Riding Hood doesn't fear the wolf, she is the wolf, and the old warnings about wandering in the woods have been replaced by invitations to even wilder territory.
abstract: Lyle Rexer reviews fairy tale-inspired photographs by Simen Johan at Yosi Milo Gallery and installations by artist Kiki Smith at Pace Wildenstein Gallery; photos (M)

snippet: Stuart Emmrich article offers advice on places to stay and dine, things to do and sights to see on 36 hour visit to Santa Monica, Calif; map; photos (M)
lead_paragraph: THOUGH only five miles or so from the heart of Los Angeles, Santa Monica feels a world away from the urban sprawl, the clogged freeways and the downtown traffic jams that make a visit to this part of Southern California often seem so maddening. Even apart from the pedestrian mall that has been created on Third Street, this ocean-front community is a town made for walkers, from the beachside promenade that was once the playground for stars like Mary Pickford and Cary Grant (and, more recently, the casts of ''Baywatch'' and ''Beverly Hills 90210'') to the famed Santa Monica Pier with its vest-pocket amusement park and its old-fashioned Ferris wheel offering spectacular views of the coastline. And though the omnipresent joggers, the preening bodybuilders and the outdoor Pilates classes might cause a moment's hesitation as you pursue your own less-ascetic activities over the weekend, pay them no mind. You're here to have a good time. The gym can wait until Monday. STUART EMMRICH
abstract: Stuart Emmrich article offers advice on places to stay and dine, things to do and sights to see on 36 hour visit to Santa Monica, Calif; map; photos (M)

snippet: Profile of and interview with German-born Parisian designer Karl Lagerfeld, 63, who is to achieve lifetime achievement award from Council of Fashion Designers of America at ceremony in New York; Lagerfeld is only leading designer without permanent...
lead_paragraph: IT'S been nearly half a century since the fashion designer Karl Lagerfeld arrived in Paris from his native Hamburg. And though he is in many ways France's most famous German émigré and has kept with him, in whatever place he has lived, a nearly exact reproduction of the bedroom he had as a child, the German word for home or motherland, heimat, doesn't exist for him.
abstract: Profile of and interview with German-born Parisian designer Karl Lagerfeld, 63, who is to achieve lifetime achievement award from Council of Fashion Designers of America at ceremony in New York; Lagerfeld is only leading designer without permanent house or his own label; photos (M)

lead_paragraph: Comic charm, like power and new money, seldom announces itself quietly in New York. This is a city that likes its humor fast, flashy and overstated, and it's rare that a Broadway comedy seduces by stealth. lead_paragraph: TO many investors, Michael G. Oxley is the Ohio Republican who put partisan politics aside and helped write legislation meant to restore investor confidence after the worst spate of corporate misconduct since the 1929 crash. ''We will not tolerate those whose greed and deception damage not only our financial marketplace but also our good will,'' Mr. Oxley said as President Bush signed the Sarbanes-Oxley bill into law in July. ''Not just money, but character, counts in America,'' he added.
abstract: TO many investors, Michael G. Oxley is the Ohio Republican who put partisan politics aside and helped write legislation meant to restore investor confidence after the worst spate of corporate misconduct since the 1929 crash. ''We will not tolerate those whose greed and deception damage not only our financial marketplace but also our good will,'' Mr. Oxley said as President Bush signed the Sarbanes-Oxley bill into law in July. ''Not just money, but character, counts in America,'' he added.    But in fact, Mr. Oxley, the chairman of the House Financial Services Committee and one of the best friends that the industry has in Washington, has worked hard to keep it from facing new regulation intended to protect investors. Early in the process, he opposed the legislation that would become Sarbanes-Oxley, preferring a softer approach to accounting overhaul. And he shrugged off the conflicts of interest among Wall Street analysts until that issue became unavoidable.

snippet: Recommendations for spending 36 hours in Williamstown, Mass; photos; maps (M)
lead_paragraph: DRIVE deep into the Berkshires on lightly traveled, two-lane highways banked by rivers and pastureland and you will soon arrive at one of the loveliest communities in New England. Williamstown, Mass., in the northwest corner of the state, is a pastoral, historic town where great art is housed in intimate settings, where academics mix with outdoorsmen, and where a weekend escape can involve everything from eavesdropping on world-famous professors in a village coffee shop to walking the northernmost reaches of the Appalachian Trail. BARBARA LAZEAR ASCHER

snippet: Pomegranates contain high levels of antioxidants and have been reputed for millennia to have therapeutic properties; almost all of nation's commercial pomegranate crop comes from San Joaquin Valley, where hot dry summers mature sweet, attractive f...
lead_paragraph: IN this age of fast fruit, the pomegranate seems a paradoxical candidate for mass appeal. Of ancient origin, celebrated in myth and art, it is regally beautiful in its leathery scarlet skin and turreted crown. Inside, it is like a treasure chest, with papery white membranes encasing hundreds of glistening garnet gems -- seeds embedded in juice sacs. The flavor is sweet-tart and winy, intense but refreshing. Pomegranates are laborious and messy to eat, however, which is probably why only 5 percent of Americans have ever tasted one.

snippet: Jonathan Reynolds article compares food served at Zeffirino and Valentino, restaurants in Las Vegas hotel modeled after Venice, with food in authentic Venice restaurants; recipe; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: Let's face it, my taste buds are only mine, not yours or anybody else's, and as such deserve no special accolade just because they temporarily have access to a printing press. This is helpful to remember not only in matters culinary but also in matters artistic, financial and romantic. For instance, now that the buffoon season is over and there are no more awards or (worse) awards shows until the billions of Emmys show up again in the fall, my easily appalled friend Jocko lays out his cards. When Jocko told me that giving the Tony to as pedestrian a show as ''Thoroughly Modern Millie'' mocks the prize and makes it meaningless as a symbol of quality because enough voters are theater owners and roadshow presenters who are not going to take a show called ''Urinetown'' on the road despite its superior originality and smarts, why those, of course, are only Jocko's taste buds, not yours or anyone else's.

lead_paragraph: ATTRACTIONS
abstract: ATTRACTIONS    Museums and Sites    AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY, Central Park West and 79th Street. On view through the holiday season, ''Origami Tree: Pocket Posey,'' featuring more than 4,000 hand-folded paper models of various flora. ''Under Antarctic Ice,'' 30 large-format photographs of mammals, fish and plants found under the ice in Antarctica, by Norbert Wu; through March 2. ''Remains of a Rainbow: Rare Plants and Animals of Hawaii,'' about 100 photographs of Hawaii's many endangered species by David Liittschwager and Susan Middleton, through March 2. ''Einstein,'' a comprehensive exhibition, with manuscripts, letters and other documents from the Albert Einstein Archives at Hebrew University; through Aug. 10. Timed admission to the exhibition, which includes museum admission, is $17; $12.50 for students and 60+; $10 for 12 and younger; free, under 2. ''The Butterfly Conservatory: Tropical Butterflies Alive in Winter,'' an exhibition of hundreds of specimens from Africa, Asia and the Americas; through May 26. In the Imax Theater, ''Bears,'' ''Kilimanjaro: To the Roof of Africa'' and ''Pulse: A Stomp Odyssey''; call for show times. Tickets to one Imax feature, including museum admission, are $17; $12.50 for students and 60+; $10 for children under 12. Admission to the Butterfly Conservatory or to the Einstein exhibition are by timed entry and include museum admission: $17; $12.50 for students and 60+; $10 for children under 12; free for children under 2. General museum admission (suggested donation): $12; $9 for students and 60+; 12 and younger, $7; under 2, free. Combination tickets available. Museum hours: daily, 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m., except Fridays, when the Rose Center is open until 8:45 p.m. for ''Starry Nights.'' Closed Christmas Day. Information: www.amnh.org, (212) 769-5100 or (212) 769-5200.

I took a seat behind her and introduced myself and she told me her name, Iva Withers.

snippet: Article by Prof Michael J Lewis says plan to rebuild World Trade Center at close to half its 110-story height is understandable; says after being attacked twice, buildings of that height might be viewed as world's largest bull's eyes; says World T...
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK is the only city in the world where the decision to build a cluster of 50- or 60-story buildings could seem an act of modesty. But such is the plan to rebuild the World Trade Center at close to half its 110-story height, as laid out by John C. Whitehead, head of the downtown redevelopment project. This is understandable. Who would duplicate a monument that had already been attacked twice, and expect tenants to move into the world's largest bull's eye? Thus the World Trade Center may well be reborn, in name and in rental capacity, but without the swagger.
abstract: Article by Prof Michael J Lewis says plan to rebuild World Trade Center at close to half its 110-story height is understandable; says after being attacked twice, buildings of that height might be viewed as world's largest bull's eyes; says World Trade Center may be reborn, but without the swagger; notes swagger appears to be on hold in many projects around country; defines term swagger building: arrogant, proud and strutting object, distinguished either by exceptional size, novel or arresting shape, or by some dazzling but purely symbolic gesture; says there will be moratorium on swagger buildings but it will not last, especially for buildings conceived during period of economic prosperity; photo of gargoyle atop Chrysler Building (M)

lead_paragraph: WHEN the 10-story Children's Hospital at Montefiore opened 13 months ago in the Bronx, it was New York City's first major hospital building in years constructed solely for children. Now construction has started in the metropolitan region on other hospitals devoted just to children.
abstract: WHEN the 10-story Children's Hospital at Montefiore opened 13 months ago in the Bronx, it was New York City's first major hospital building in years constructed solely for children. Now construction has started in the metropolitan region on other hospitals devoted just to children.    The efforts involve hundreds of millions of dollars and reflect recent changes in the philosophy of how hospitalized children should be treated. Those changes are immediately visible in architecture that features bright colors, an intimate scale and touches of whimsy designed to make hospitals nonthreatening and welcoming rather than distant and forbidding.

lead_paragraph: ARTHUR AVENUE in the Bronx cultivates the image of ''Cucina Paradiso,'' complete with a booming soundtrack by Dean Martin at his sappiest. It would be easy to write the neighborhood off as a culinary theme park, a Neapolitan Epcot Center staffed by stock characters. There's the vegetable vendor in the ''Arthur Avenue since 1936'' jacket; the cheese and salami sellers who cannot let a passer-by pass by without insisting, ''Taste this!''; the grandmas in flowered aprons watching over their displays of basil and eggplant under boughs of hot peppers hung up to dry.

Iron Man No. 2    Like his hero, Cal Ripken Jr., he was a Maryland man, named after his father and known for his steely resolve. He too had estimable talents, but coasting was anathema: whenever nature didn't give him a boost, he just worked harder. And he always, always showed up. So Alan Linton Jr.'s buddies gave him his idol's nickname -- the Iron Man.

snippet: A O Scott reviews several offerings in New York Video Center: Guy Maddin's Dracula: From a Virgin's Diary; Mike Mills's documentaries Meet Mike Mills, Architecture of Reassurance, and Paperboys; Helen Stickler's Stoked; and Joe Carroll and Ben Hol...
lead_paragraph: FOR at least half a century, video has been the art form of the future, where the technological vanguard meets the cultural avant-garde. It therefore seems strange, even a little perverse, that the centerpiece of this year's New York Video Festival, which opens tonight at Lincoln Center, is not a collage of digital imagery or information-age self-reflection, but a silent, black-and-white adaptation of Bram Stoker's ''Dracula.'' Made for Canadian television by the Winnipeg-based experimental filmmaker Guy Maddin, ''Dracula: Pages From a Virgin's Diary,'' which will be shown at the Walter Reade Theater tonight at 9, is less a remake of the earlier cinematic versions of the vampire story than a pre-make, an attempt to imagine what the tale might have looked like before F. W. Murnau, before Bela Lugosi, before Francis Ford Coppola.
abstract: A O Scott reviews several offerings in New York Video Center: Guy Maddin's Dracula: From a Virgin's Diary; Mike Mills's documentaries Meet Mike Mills, Architecture of Reassurance, and Paperboys; Helen Stickler's Stoked; and Joe Carroll and Ben Holtzman's Between Resistance and Community; Festival schedule; photos (L)

snippet: Douglas Century examines hip-hop's intense love affair with car culture; describes collection of rebuilt vintage cars owned by popular DJ Funkmaster Flex, who has established his own car-customizing club; photos (M)
lead_paragraph: Just after midnight on a rain-slicked stretch of Manhattan's West Side Highway, Funkmaster Flex is taking a joy ride in his new toy, a gleaming 1966 Chevrolet Impala rolling on customized chrome wheels. ''This is my favorite old-school ride,'' Flex tells me with a broad smile. ''I'm so proud of this car because it took three years to get it together.'' The Impala's paint is a candy-apple red; its dashboard is festooned with sharp angles of spotless chrome; the seats are made from brand-new, buttery black leather that makes the interior smell like a Roche-Bobois showroom. Idling at a red light, the 454-horsepower engine strains under us like some caged ogre.

snippet: Comment on linking one's personal computer to one's home stereo--using computer to store and organize music into customized playlists while leaving playback duties to home stereo; drawings illustrate connections (M)
lead_paragraph: ASIDE from the talking garden gnome and the combined baseball hat and glove, few devices have ever been asked to do more than the personal computer. Lately it is being called upon to function as a stereo. But most people already own one of those, and usually it is in a room better suited to listening to music. Is there a way, then, to use your PC for what it's good at -- storing and organizing music into customized playlists -- while leaving playback duties to the real thing, your home stereo?
abstract: Comment on linking one's personal computer to one's home stereo--using computer to store and organize music into customized playlists while leaving playback duties to home stereo; drawings illustrate connections (M)

snippet: Raimund Abraham, architect of Austrian Cultural Forum on East 52nd Street, Manhattan, says imagery of new building is intended to help Austria's ambition to shed its quaint Old World reputation--land of marzipan sculptures and flouncy waltzes--and...
lead_paragraph: RAIMUND ABRAHAM, the architect of the Austrian Cultural Forum, which opens next month, has compared the building's tilting zinc facade to the slicing blades of a guillotine. The imagery may be severe, but it serves Austria's ambition to shed its quaint Old World reputation -- land of marzipan sculptures and flouncy waltzes -- and update it with something unmistakably contemporary. Kenneth Frampton, the architectural historian, called the building, on East 52nd Street, ''the most significant modern piece of architecture to be realized in Manhattan since the Seagram Building and the Guggenheim Museum of 1959.''
abstract: Raimund Abraham, architect of Austrian Cultural Forum on East 52nd Street, Manhattan, says imagery of new building is intended to help Austria's ambition to shed its quaint Old World reputation--land of marzipan sculptures and flouncy waltzes--and update it with something unmistakably contemporary; on March 1, month before building's debut as Austria's showcase abroad, Abraham renounced his Austrian citizenship and became American; move was carefully deliberated reaction to government he feels is out of step with culturally enlightened country he loves; photos (L)

lead_paragraph: IF the world's major athletic spectacle is to invade a small American town -- and needs to be fed around the clock -- it might as well be Park City. This well-preserved former mining settlement, now a wealthy year-round resort, appears well braced for the challenge. With more than 100 restaurants, a dynamic business district (Main Street will be a pedestrian mall during the games) and well-regimented civic planning, this giant communal meal may well come off, if not seamlessly, at least with minimal broken china.

lead_paragraph: IT would be hard for the responsive traveler from Britain or America to visit the city of Dresden without some unease. The British-American fire-bombing of February 1945 has become an epic of the Second World War, and, like epics of earlier wars, acquires a deeper resonance every year through argument, refining and retelling. It is part of all our histories, and provides the inescapable context within which to marvel at what survived in Dresden, what has been restored, and what is happening there now.

lead_paragraph: A few months ago, on Nov. 5, 2001, to be exact, The Wall Street Journal ran an odd report from Tehran. Thousands of young Iranians had taken to the streets to wave American flags and chant pro-American slogans. They had responded to the appeal of Reza Pahlavi, son of the former shah, who lives in Maryland and addressed the Iranian people via a call-in television talk show broadcast from North Hollywood, Calif. In Iran there were enough satellite television dishes and enough people watching what came through them that a man on a telephone call to Los Angeles could hijack a demonstration on the streets of Tehran.

lead_paragraph: DON'T be alarmed by the sound of glasses smashing behind the white onyx bar at Washington Park, as they did with alarming frequency the day I was there. The restaurant had only been open for a week, and a certain amount of chaos was expected. Never mind that the martinis that night had to be served in riesling glasses. Heed instead the long-held superstition that when a glass breaks it signals a change in karma: whatever energies have been pulling you one way, the direction changes and you are headed, with luck, to a better place.

lead_paragraph: It's a strange phenomenon but a true one: sometimes there's nothing like reading a pile of gleaming new cookbooks to put you off your feed. It's not that most cookbooks are badly written and killingly earnest, though they are. It's not that you can usually find better versions of most of the ''new'' recipes in older cookbooks (probably ones you already own), though you can. The real problem is one that I couldn't put my finger on until I stumbled across my copy of Phillip Lopate's 1989 book ''Against Joie de Vivre.''

snippet: Herbert Muschamp review of Mood River, new design show at Wexner Center for the Arts in Columbus, Ohio; photos (M)
lead_paragraph: ''MOOD RIVER,'' the beguiling new design show at the Wexner Center for the Arts in Columbus, Ohio, goes to your head like a sip of sparkling burgundy brew. But it won't take away your hunger for meat and potatoes. Subjectivity, atmosphere, the idea that ambience can be more powerful than blocks of solid matter: these are among the defining motifs in contemporary architecture and design. There is a need for an exhibition that explores these themes with analytic precision. ''Mood River'' doesn't satisfy that need. Rather, it is an extravagant demonstration in installation techniques, a window display of waves in search of depth.
abstract: Herbert Muschamp review of Mood River, new design show at Wexner Center for the Arts in Columbus, Ohio; photos (M)

lead_paragraph: WALKING up Madison Avenue through the usual thicket of cellphones, I heard my first interesting snatch of conversation since that accursed invention forced an avalanche of inanities on our ears. A woman was saying: ''He's a bastard. Justified homicide.'' She didn't have to mention the quality of the food on Rikers Island for me to know she was one of us, the not-so-secret addicts of ''Law and Order,'' Dick Wolf's long-running, ubiquitously syndicated, hydra-headed NBC series about New York cops and district attorneys. I know it's a hit of major proportions around the country, too. Its ratings are phenomenal. Like Woody Allen, it travels better than you'd think.
abstract: Molly Haskell article on how Law and Order, Dick Wolf's phenomenally successful television drama series and its spinoffs, Special Victims Unit and Criminal Intent, have become more of a consolation and diversion for New York City fans since September 11 terrorist attacks; photos; drawing; chart (L)

lead_paragraph: TUCKED into a booth at Ben's Kosher Delicatessen in Baldwin, Don Lerman of Levittown gripped a knife in his right hand, quickly slicing baseball-size matzo balls into quarters like apples and shoveling one after the other into his mouth with his left. His fingers quivered. Crumbs dribbled down his chin and stuck in his beard. He didn't pause until he had devoured 12 of the half-pound dumplings in two minutes and 50 seconds, just beating out Eric Booker of Copiague, who gulped only 11 3/4.

snippet: Dwight Gardner article on horror writer Clive Barker and four children's books he is writing for HarperCollins that are are based on paintings he has done that create fantasy world he calls Abarat; notes that even before he began writing books and...
lead_paragraph: Clive Barker is not a scary guy. At 50, he is tanned and buff and amiable -- his big vices are cigars and endless cups of strong tea. With his trimmed goatee and twin hoop earrings he looks like a pirate who is settling into middle age after years of successful plundering. But when he cracks open the door to one of his Beverly Hills houses -- Barker owns three of them, all in a row, all with wide-angle views over Century City -- and croaks, ''Welcome to the inside of my head,'' I can't help it: I get a little creeped-out anyway.

lead_paragraph: AFTER a high-powered career as lead guitarist for bands like the Jefferson Airplane and Hot Tuna, Jorma Kaukonen knew what he wanted to do, and it wasn't to play big arenas with smoke machines and light shows while his hair turned gray. His idea was to start a guitar camp here in the rolling hills of Ohio, where students could commune with nature and immerse themselves in the pure, acoustic blues made famous by musicians like Robert Johnson and Mr. Kaukonen's idol, the Rev. Gary Davis.

snippet: "To Vivienne, the handsome American symbolised the heroic spirit of the Wild West . . . but she had mistaken her man. It was to be but one of several fundamental misunderstandings."
lead_paragraph: Oxford was losing its young men. It was the winter of 1914, and the streets were unnaturally quiet, the quadrangles deserted by those undergraduates who had joined the British army. But the university was not entirely empty. A number of Americans had arrived to fill the gaps, to the extent that at Merton College the Junior Common Room proposed the motion, "that this society abhors the Americanisation of Oxford." The resolution failed by two votes, after a recently arrived graduate student in philosophy named Thomas Stearns Eliot pointed out to his fellows how much they owed to "Amurrican culcher . . . in the movies, in music, in the cocktail, and in the dance."

snippet: Josephine Schmidt travel article on spas in Karlovy Vary, Czech Republic; photos; map (L)
lead_paragraph: IN Saratoga I've sipped the waters, in Montecatini I've had dense Tuscan mud slapped on my face, and in Yalta a skin-searing sauna and sea-water dunk left me tingling for days. Yet in all of these places, however pleasant, I thought of Karlovy Vary. A proper spa vacation, I've decided, really requires grand colonnades and meandering wooded paths for ambling, plenty of little shops that transform small luxuries into absolute necessities and a dietary regimen that encourages abundant helpings of whipped cream.

snippet: Jonathan Reynolds interview with George Foreman, former boxing champ whose Lean Mean Fat Reducing Grilling Machine has become trendiest household appliance on Manhattan's Upper East Side; Salton recently bought Foreman out for $138 million, after ...
lead_paragraph: I wonder if the gifted but unknown illustrator -- and rabid anti-Steinbergian -- Luas Grebniets had a good cackle parodying his nemesis Saul Steinberg's most famous work. You will recall this work, a New Yorker cover, because reproductions of it hang in just about every apartment in this city. It pictures the Big Appler's world basically ending at the Hudson, with California in another solar system and Russia somewhere beyond California. Although Steinberg intended it as a satire of our provincialism, most people who say they like satire don't actually like being satirized, and so they embraced the illustration as emblematic of New York's pre-eminent, if not apotheotic, status in the world. Grebniets's mirror image looks at the globe as a Midwesterner does, picturing New York as quite a small little dot, though a noisy dot, one that, while believing itself the discoverer of all things fashionable, is frequently a dot woefully behind the American curve.
abstract: Jonathan Reynolds interview with George Foreman, former boxing champ whose Lean Mean Fat Reducing Grilling Machine has become trendiest household appliance on Manhattan's Upper East Side; Salton recently bought Foreman out for $138 million, after he had already earned $50- to $60-million as ardent pitchman; photos; salmon recipe (special section, Fashions of The Times) (part 2 of 2-part section) (M)

He nudges the chocolate gently with a spoon. ''Go slow now, don't burn it.'' He wheels around and pours sugar into a stainless-steel bowl filled with eggs. ''But I got nothing against the woman,' I told them. 'Most people would say something bad about her,' this interviewer kept prodding me, and I said to him, 'Well, I'm not most people.'''

snippet: New York is still New York, one year after it faced its own mortality; it has not been unmade by terrorist attack on World Trade Center year ago, but remade; its sense of control and invulnerability is gone, but New York has become city of regener...
lead_paragraph: NOTHING has been forgotten. That could never be. But things go on, start anew, revert to some mean. Even on the E train downtown, where the stations still advise, ''To World Trade Center all times,'' and the conductors intone, ''E train to World Trade.'' One year after it faced its own mortality, New York, in its daily curiosities and unexpungeable flavor, is still New York. For some time, no one knew if that could happen.
abstract: New York is still New York, one year after it faced its own mortality; it has not been unmade by terrorist attack on World Trade Center year ago, but remade; its sense of control and invulnerability is gone, but New York has become city of regeneration; it is a city pulsing with added exertion to be normal--its own kind of normal; it is also a city with its fingers crossed, as its citizenry hangs in delicate equipoise between faith and fear; photos (L)

lead_paragraph: DESPITE the recent advent of Starbucks and other, domestically spawned chains of inexpensive coffee shops in Tokyo, there still exists a genteel tea parlor culture where utterly divine cakes are consumed with leisure in classy salons. These confectionery-shops-cum-cafes, invariably in upscale residential neighborhoods, are mostly inspired by French patisseries.

JOHN ABERCROMBIE QUARTET, Jazz Standard, 116 East 27th Street, Manhattan, (212) 576-2232. Mr. Abercrombie, the guitarist, has made his name on the ECM label, and he makes some sensitive, deep-listening records. His latest, ''Cat 'n' Mouse,'' with the lineup that plays at the Jazz Standard this week (Mark Feldman on violin, Joey Baron on drums, Marc Johnson on bass), is his best in a long time. Tonight through Sunday night at 7:30 and 9:30, with an 11:30 set tonight and tomorrow; cover charge is $20 (Ben Ratliff).

snippet: "Blackwood looked only forward, never back: the cuffs of history never locked about his wrists and throat."
lead_paragraph: ON A DECEMBER MORNING in 1944, Mr. Andrew Jackson Blackwood—a young-faced, self-made man who had been in California twelve or fourteen years, depending on whom you asked—was making his way down El Camino Real. He was driving his yellow Imperial Victoria on his way to a real-estate convention in San Diego. At present he was somewhere between Dana Point and Oceanside, but many miles back his Automobile Club map had flown out the window, the wings of its paper-folds extending and flapping away. The fluttery movement—and the car’s sudden swerve as he lunged for the accordioned map—made him think of a large, ancient bird lifting itself into extinction. This was a more morose thought than Blackwood was used to, and it didn’t stay with him, flitting away like the map itself. But Blackwood had a sense of direction, he liked to tell himself, and he continued on his way.
abstract: "Blackwood looked only forward, never back: the cuffs of history never locked about his wrists and throat."

snippet: Mark Levine profile of Bryan Buckley, who has directed number of acclaimed television commercials, including standouts from Super Bowl games; says that his 'films,' viewed consecutively, without intervening distractions of television programming, ...
lead_paragraph: On a bright morning in early January, a wound-up and highly competitive man named Bryan Buckley arrives for work in an industrial section of Queens not long after sunrise. He is preparing for his fourth consecutive appearance in the Super Bowl. He wears Nikes, a pair of sagging nylon running pants, a white T-shirt and a baseball cap. He is surrounded by carpenters, electricians, designers, costumers, stylists, men perched at computer monitors and wearing headsets, men holding binders and wearing worried expressions, caterers, corporate executives, recipients of Academy and Tony Awards, a greasy-looking fellow in a tuxedo and ruffled shirt and 9 or 10 young women dressed as beauty queens. Buckley, 38, directs television commercials. This one, promoting Oxygen Media, owners of a cable channel aimed at female viewers, involves a lavish tongue-in-cheek reconstruction of three generations of beauty pageants. Hence Buckley's workplace -- a cavernous sound stage at Silvercup Studios -- is littered with artifacts that might belong in a pop-culture shrine: a green wall covered with a spray of vibrantly fake flowers; a corkscrew-shaped red velvet lounge chair; an enormous Pop Art cutout of the face of the Statue of Liberty.
abstract: Mark Levine profile of Bryan Buckley, who has directed number of acclaimed television commercials, including standouts from Super Bowl games; says that his 'films,' viewed consecutively, without intervening distractions of television programming, form something like a coherent body of work: inventive, vital and full of ideas; photos (M)

Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.    Art Fairs    ''ARMORY PHOTOGRAPHY SHOW 2002,'' Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, North Pavilion, 11th Avenue at 39th Street. Hours: Today through Sunday, 11 a.m. to 7 p.m.; Monday, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission: $15. Information: (212) 645-6440. The organizers of the Armory Show, which began six years ago in the Gramercy Park Hotel and now fills two piers on the Hudson every February, are bringing forth a spinoff, the Armory Photography Show 2002. Its 83 participants will include contemporary art galleries, including Barbara Gladstone, 303, Matthew Marks, David Zwirner, Team, Greene-Naftali and Lelong, as well as stalwarts of the photography scene like Fraenkel, Howard Greenberg, Julie Saul, Robert Mann and Klotz-Sirmon -- a combination that promises to reflect the way the medium's widespread and expanding presence. A broad range of modern and contemporary material -- some of it freshly minted -- will be presented, along with some videos and occasional single-artist shows and installations (Roberta Smith).

snippet: Mim Udovitch article on online community of anorexic teenage girls and young women, who use their Web sites to support one another, not in struggle to overcome their eating disorders but rather in embrace of thinness as lifestyle; photo (L)
lead_paragraph: Claire is 18. She is a pretty teenager, with long strawberry-blond hair, and she is almost abnormally self-possessed for a girl from a small town who has suddenly been descended upon by a big-city reporter who is there to talk to her, in secret, about her secret life. She is sitting on the track that runs around the field of her high school's football stadium, wearing running shorts and a T-shirt and shivering a little because even though we are in Florida -- in the kind of town where, according to Claire, during ''season'' when you see yet another car with New York plates, you just feel like running it down -- there's an evening chill.
abstract: Mim Udovitch article on online community of anorexic teenage girls and young women, who use their Web sites to support one another, not in struggle to overcome their eating disorders but rather in embrace of thinness as lifestyle; photo (L)

snippet: Marian Burros describes new breed of restaurant in San Francisco Bay area that are devoted entirely to serving small portions of serious food; recipes; photos (L)
lead_paragraph: ON a recent warm evening at À Côté, a tiny new restaurant in Oakland, a stylish, electric young crowd was standing nose to nose, drinks in hand, spilling over into the aisles and cheerfully waiting to claim tiny tables. Once seated, they would cover their tables with tiny plates of food of almost every description: mussels with Pernod, saffron pappardelle with rabbit, broccoli raab flatbread, skate wing with beets. And they would sip ''flights'' of four tiny glasses of wine.

snippet: Gary Taubes article says that American medical establishment may have caused nation's obesity epidemic by recommending low-fat, high-carbohydrate diet for last 25 years and that Dr Robert Atkins may well have been right all along in telling Americ...
lead_paragraph: If the members of the American medical establishment were to have a collective find-yourself-standing-naked-in-Times-Square-type nightmare, this might be it. They spend 30 years ridiculing Robert Atkins, author of the phenomenally-best-selling ''Dr. Atkins' Diet Revolution'' and ''Dr. Atkins' New Diet Revolution,'' accusing the Manhattan doctor of quackery and fraud, only to discover that the unrepentant Atkins was right all along. Or maybe it's this: they find that their very own dietary recommendations -- eat less fat and more carbohydrates -- are the cause of the rampaging epidemic of obesity in America. Or, just possibly this: they find out both of the above are true.
abstract: Gary Taubes article says that American medical establishment may have caused nation's obesity epidemic by recommending low-fat, high-carbohydrate diet for last 25 years and that Dr Robert Atkins may well have been right all along in telling Americans that they can lose weight by eating all the fatty foods they want and skipping carbohydrates; says Americans' total calorie intake has risen considerably under government-recommended diet because of way carbohydrates affect blood sugar and insulin and thus appetite; notes research indicating that ketosis, hunger-reducing mechanism in Atkins diet, is safe, that Atkins-like diets can be more effective at weight reduction than low-fat diets and that they may even be better for the heart; welcomes NIH's belated decision to finance comparative studies of popular diets; photos (L)

snippet: Mimi Sheraton article on delectable street food at night markets in Beijing and Xian, from familiar Chinese dumplings to exotic offerings; photos (special section, The Sophisticated Traveler) (part 2 of 2-part section) (M)
lead_paragraph: Whatever wonders lure other visitors back to China, my favorite memories were of the delectable street foods I enjoyed throughout the country in 1986. On my return last June, I was both surprised and delighted to see that Beijing had become a gleaming metropolis with broad, tree-lined avenues, excellent new hotels and an immaculate, quick and quiet subway. But I feared this might mean that the markets and back alleys where I had sampled so many savory snacks had been modernized out of existence. Fortunately, I worried in vain, for while a few have disappeared, many remain, dispensing specialties with great flair and showmanship and giving visitors a chance to sample the world's most succulent and inexpensive fast food.
abstract: Mimi Sheraton article on delectable street food at night markets in Beijing and Xian, from familiar Chinese dumplings to exotic offerings; photos (special section, The Sophisticated Traveler) (part 2 of 2-part section) (M)
